revision.text:
[[File:Strawberries on sale in Australia with tampering notice.jpg|thumb|Strawberries on sale in Coles with a notice advising customers to inspect and cut up strawberries before consuming them]] An ongoing [[food safety]] crisis in which numerous [[punnet]]s of [[strawberry|strawberries]] grown in [[Queensland]] and [[Western Australia]] were found to be contaminated with needles began in September 2018. [[Queensland Police]] reported that by November 2018, there had been 186 reports of contamination nationally.
==Contamination== On 9 September 2018, several days prior to any official announcement of contamination, a [[Facebook]] user posted a warning about Berry Obsession strawberries purchased from [[Woolworths Supermarkets|Woolworths]] [[Strathpine Centre]] in [[Moreton Bay Regional Council|Moreton Bay]], north of [[Brisbane]]. The user reported that his friend had swallowed part of a needle and was in the [[emergency department]] at hospital. A second victim had called Woolworths on 11 September. The affected strawberries were not withdrawn and the contamination first publicly reported until 12 September. In the following days, dozens of contaminated punnets of strawberries grown in Queensland and Western Australia were discovered in NSW, South Australia, Victoria and Tasmania.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/annastacia-palaszczuk-pledges-1m-for-strawberry-growers-as-vision-emerges-of-dumped-berries/news-story/cabbecbb53cbd3c71d5d1edb5eb857c1|title=Student ‘lies’ about strawberry injury as Annastacia Palaszczuk promises $1m for growers|last=Owens|first=Jared|last2=McKenna|first2=Michael|date=18 September 2018|website=www.theaustralian.com.au|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-18|subscription=yes|last3=Taylor|first3=Paige}}</ref>
Some cases are believed to be hoaxes. A South Australian man was arrested on September 21 after faking a contamination,<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.news.com.au/national/south-australia/adelaide-man-charged-over-strawberry-contamination-claim/news-story/07df1a7705958e2850df4ea663212ccc |title=Adelaide man charged over strawberry contamination claim |access-date=2018-09-21 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180921113444/https://www.news.com.au/national/south-australia/adelaide-man-charged-over-strawberry-contamination-claim/news-story/07df1a7705958e2850df4ea663212ccc |archive-date=2018-09-21 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> and will face court in November.<ref>{{cite news |title=Adelaide man stands by needle in strawberry claim |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-10-24/sa-man-in-court-over-false-strawberry-needle-report/10423036 |accessdate=24 October 2018 |work=ABC News |date=24 October 2018 |language=en-AU}}</ref>
==Affected brands== As of 16 September 2018, the following brands have been identified by authorities as being involved in the contamination:
Strawberries grown in Queensland: *Donnybrook Berries *Love Berry *Delightful Strawberries *Oasis brands *Berry Obsession *Berry Licious
Strawberries grown in Western Australia: *Mal's Black Label *Australian Choice
Police and state health authorities have recommend consumers either dispose of affected brands or return to place of purchase. They also recommend consumers cut up other brands before eating. Queensland chief health officer Dr Jeannette Young stated that "If they do have any strawberries it would be safest to dispose of them."
Both Coles and Aldi removed all strawberries from their shelves, but planned to restock after 18 September. Woolworths had removed affected brands only.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-18/strawberry-fund-set-up-for-farmers-qld-premier-says/10262804|title=Strawberry growers plead for common sense, accuse authorities of mishandling issue|last=Bavas|first=Josh|date=2018-09-18|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-09-18|language=en-AU|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180918163445/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-18/strawberry-fund-set-up-for-farmers-qld-premier-says/10262804|archive-date=2018-09-18|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> Woolworths later removed sewing needles from sale as a temporary measure.<ref>{{cite news |title=Woolworths to stop selling sewing needles amid fruit contamination scare |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-20/woolworths-dumps-needle-sales-due-to-fruit-contamination/10285368 |accessdate=20 September 2018 |work=ABC News |date=20 September 2018 |language=en-AU |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180921022150/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-20/woolworths-dumps-needle-sales-due-to-fruit-contamination/10285368 |archive-date=2018-09-21 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> On 23 September, needles were found in "Australian Choice" brand strawberries sold in Auckland, New Zealand.<ref>{{cite news |title=Australian strawberries pulled from New Zealand shelves after needles found |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/sep/23/australian-strawberries-pulled-from-new-zealand-shelves-after-needles-found |work=the Guardian |date=23 September 2018 |language=en |access-date=2018-09-23 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180923105125/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/sep/23/australian-strawberries-pulled-from-new-zealand-shelves-after-needles-found |archive-date=2018-09-23 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
==Response== ===Investigation=== The Queensland Strawberry Growers Association initially stated they had "reason to suspect" a "disgruntled" former packing employee was responsible for the contamination.<ref name="Strawberry recall">{{cite news |last1=Vujkovic |first1=Melanie |last2=Horn |first2=Allyson |date=13 September 2018 |title=Strawberry recall: Disgruntled ex-employee believed to be behind sewing needles in strawberries |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-12/strawberry-investigation-after-sewing-needles-found-inside/10237954 |work=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |location= |access-date=16 September 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180915153134/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-12/strawberry-investigation-after-sewing-needles-found-inside/10237954 |archive-date=2018-09-15 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> [[Queensland Police]] Acting Chief Superintendent Terry Lawrence subsequently cast doubt upon that theory, stating "This was an earlier comment by the Strawberry Growers Association, it's something we don't subscribe to".<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Strawberry contamination prompts $100,000 reward in search for culprit |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-15/strawberry-contamination-prompts-100000-reward/10250876 |work=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |location= |date=13 September 2018 |access-date=16 September 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180915143939/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-15/strawberry-contamination-prompts-100000-reward/10250876 |archive-date=2018-09-15 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> Adrian Schultz, the vice-president of the Queensland Strawberry Growers Association described the contamination as an act of "commercial terrorism".<ref>{{cite news |last=Siddique |first=Haroon |date=17 September 2018 |title=Strawberry needle sabotage scare spreads to all six Australian states |url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/sep/17/australian-police-say-needle-found-in-banana-as-strawberry-sabotage-spreads |work=[[The Guardian]] |location=[[Sydney]] |access-date=18 September 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180917171250/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/sep/17/australian-police-say-needle-found-in-banana-as-strawberry-sabotage-spreads |archive-date=2018-09-17 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> Tony Holl, a strawberry grower from Western Australia told the ABC that he believed someone had a "vendetta" against the strawberry industry, suggesting otherwise the contamination could be a "terrorist act".<ref name="ABC metal detectors">{{cite news |last1=Weber |first1=David |last2=Prendergast |first2=Jo |date=17 September 2018 |title=Strawberry needle scare: Growers to look to metal detectors to contain contamination crisis|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-17/wa-drawn-into-strawberry-contamination-scare/10254746 |work=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |location= |access-date=18 September 2018}}</ref>
The [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] reported on Thursday that "Police believe they have contained the threat and assured consumers would be able to safely buy strawberries again from Thursday, when stock is replaced."<ref name="Strawberry recall"/>
As of 19 September, [[Queensland Police]] have more than 100 officers, including 60 detectives, working on the investigation into the contamination.<ref>{{cite news |last=Caldwell |first=Felicity |date=19 September 2018 |title=Strawberry copycats are wasting police time, says Queensland Premier |url=https://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/politics/queensland/strawberry-copycats-are-wasting-police-time-says-queensland-premier-20180919-p504ms.html |work=[[Brisbane Times]] |location=[[Brisbane]] |access-date=23 September 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180923235049/https://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/politics/queensland/strawberry-copycats-are-wasting-police-time-says-queensland-premier-20180919-p504ms.html |archive-date=2018-09-23 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> However, by 15 October [[Queensland Police]] scaled this back to one full time detective amid a lack of clear leads.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/business/consumer-affairs/queensland-police-scale-back-strawberry-probe-to-one-full-time-detective-20181015-p509ti.html|title=Queensland police scale back strawberry probe to one full-time detective|first=Mark|last=Solomons|date=15 October 2018|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=12 November 2018}}</ref>
===Government response=== On 15 September 2018, Queensland Premier [[Annastacia Palaszczuk]] announced a $100,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of anyone responsible for the sabotage.<ref>{{cite news |last=Crockford |first=Toby |date=15 September 2018 |title=Queensland Premier puts $100,000 bounty on strawberry saboteur |url=https://www.smh.com.au/national/queensland/queensland-premier-puts-100-000-bounty-on-strawberry-saboteur-20180915-p503y4.html |work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] |location=[[Sydney]] |access-date=16 September 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180915054601/https://www.smh.com.au/national/queensland/queensland-premier-puts-100-000-bounty-on-strawberry-saboteur-20180915-p503y4.html |archive-date=2018-09-15 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> On 18 September, Palaszczuk announced a $1 million assistance package for the strawberry industry in the state, telling State Parliament that "This past week, Queensland has been the victim of an ugly, calculated and despicable crime."<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Govt funding for Qld strawberry industry |url=https://www.9news.com.au/national/2018/09/18/17/21/govt-funding-for-qld-strawberry-industry |work=[[Nine News]] |location= |date=18 September 2018 |access-date=18 September 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180918103823/https://www.9news.com.au/national/2018/09/18/17/21/govt-funding-for-qld-strawberry-industry |archive-date=2018-09-18 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://statements.qld.gov.au/Statement/2018/9/18/palaszczuk-government-commits-1-million-to-strawberry-farmers|title=Palaszczuk Government commits $1 million to strawberry farmers|publisher=|accessdate=18 September 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180918160841/http://statements.qld.gov.au/Statement/2018/9/18/palaszczuk-government-commits-1-million-to-strawberry-farmers|archive-date=2018-09-18|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> Also on 18 September, Premier of Western Australia [[Mark McGowan]] announced a $100,000 reward for information leading to a prosecution.<ref>{{cite news |last=Colvin |first=Ali |date=18 September 2018 |title=Strawberry needle scare: WA Government offers $100k reward for information |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-18/strawberry-needle-scare-contamination-reward-western-australia/10264502 |work=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |location= |access-date=18 September 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180918163507/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-18/strawberry-needle-scare-contamination-reward-western-australia/10264502 |archive-date=2018-09-18 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
The two largest food retailers in [[New Zealand]], [[Woolworths NZ]] and [[Foodstuffs]] announced they would be removing Australian-grown strawberries from their shelves.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title='Commercial terrorism' has brought strawberry industry to its knees - NZ supermarket chains stop Aussie imports over needle concerns |url=https://www.tvnz.co.nz/one-news/new-zealand/commercial-terrorism-has-brought-strawberry-industry-its-knees-nz-supermarket-chains-stop-aussie-imports-over-needle-concerns |work=[[TVNZ]] |location= |date=17 September 2018 |access-date=18 September 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180917224630/https://www.tvnz.co.nz/one-news/new-zealand/commercial-terrorism-has-brought-strawberry-industry-its-knees-nz-supermarket-chains-stop-aussie-imports-over-needle-concerns |archive-date=2018-09-17 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
On 18 September 2018, Senator [[Bridget McKenzie]], the Minister for Regional Services, issued a media statement, describing the contamination as "deliberate sabotage" and urging consumers to "exercise caution and cut up their fruit before consumption."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.health.gov.au/internet/ministers/publishing.nsf/Content/health-mediarel-yr2018-mckenzie062.htm|title=Media Statement – Strawberries|first=McKenzie, Bridget. Minister for Regional Services. Minister for|last=Sport.|website=www.health.gov.au|accessdate=18 September 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180918091018/http://www.health.gov.au/internet/ministers/publishing.nsf/Content/health-mediarel-yr2018-mckenzie062.htm|archive-date=2018-09-18|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
====Criticism of response==== As of 17 September 2018, a consumer-level food recall of any affected brands has yet to be issued. Instead, only a "trade recall" has been issued. [[Food Standards Australia New Zealand]] describes a trade recall as a recall "conducted when the food has not been sold directly to consumers. It involves recovery of the product from distribution centres and wholesalers".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foodstandards.gov.au/industry/foodrecalls/recalls/pages/whatisafoodrecall.aspx|title=What is a food recall|website=www.foodstandards.gov.au|accessdate=16 September 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180916235806/http://www.foodstandards.gov.au/industry/foodrecalls/recalls/pages/whatisafoodrecall.aspx|archive-date=2018-09-16|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> Professor Melissa Fitzgerald, a food safety expert at the [[University of Queensland]], told the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] she was "surprised" there had not been a consumer-level recall given the products had been sold to individual customers. The recall was not mentioned on supermarket or government food safety websites—something Professor Fitzgerald would have expected. Professor Fitzgerald said "I would expect people to go to the websites for information...People may be quite surprised not to find any information on the websites where they normally would." Professor Fitzgerald criticised the delay between the first incident on 9 September and the public warning on 12 September.<ref>{{cite news |last=Gartry |first=Laura |date=14 September 2018 |title=Needles in strawberries: Food expert says Government's recall response not appropriate |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-14/safety-response-to-strawberry-tampered-with-needles-not-enough/10242700 |work=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |location= |access-date=16 September 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180915165336/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-14/safety-response-to-strawberry-tampered-with-needles-not-enough/10242700 |archive-date=2018-09-15 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
Queensland Strawberry Industry Development Officer Jennifer Rowling accused "some authoritative spokespeople" of mishandling the response to the incident. She also criticised a "sometimes hysterical media" and accused them of costing agricultural businesses millions of dollars. Rowling insisted only three brands had been affected and said "All other reported cases have either been copycats or unsubstantiated claims."<ref>{{cite news |last=Bavas |first=Josh |date=18 September 2018 |title=Strawberry needle tampering crisis: Queensland growers call for 'calm and common sense' |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-18/strawberry-fund-set-up-for-farmers-qld-premier-says/10262804 |work=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |location= |access-date=18 September 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180918163445/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-18/strawberry-fund-set-up-for-farmers-qld-premier-says/10262804 |archive-date=2018-09-18 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
=== Grower measures and responses === On 15 September, Suncoast Harvest farm of the Sunshine Coast announced on Facebook<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/thesuncoastharvest/posts/444593375947193?__xts__%5B0%5D=68.ARAxnBa6hBvO2KaTpeAKgo3xr0cUeYOwC8m6D9hJMqBleAAcnWKxJ1OBX3BEkmEXIuF805LYTaPDc8fdcq7C-tVDD3_JCpy1sSHzMzc3rW1WmcTyj9WaID1yD1NARurwn5qFv8kID1xIitBkxrKWk_XE3GYGum0DT5fRM6dfg226yv9ObEVu&__tn__=-R|title=Suncoast Harvest|last=|first=|date=15 September 2018|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-18}}</ref> that they were ceasing growing strawberries for the remainder of the year, resulting in job losses for 100 workers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Strawberry sabotage leaves 100 out of work|last=|first=|date=19 September 2018|work=Sunshine Coast Daily|access-date=|page=10}}</ref> Some growers started ordering and installing [[metal detector]]s to protect their strawberries from contamination.<ref name="ABC metal detectors"/>
Some farms have had to dispose of strawberries in response to the crisis. Donnybrook Berries of Queensland, one of the brands affected, dumped truckloads of berries, sharing the resulting video footage which went viral with over a million views in a day.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pedestrian.tv/news/strawberry-queensland-waste-video/|title=Video Of QLD Berry Farmer's Tragic Wastage Goes Viral As Scandal Continues|last=Adams|first=David|date=2018-09-18|work=Pedestrian TV|access-date=2018-09-18|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180918193936/https://www.pedestrian.tv/news/strawberry-queensland-waste-video/|archive-date=2018-09-18|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> One Queensland farm burned off 500,000 strawberry plants deemed unsellable, as it was cheaper than harvesting.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/drastic-new-measures-strawberry-farmers-taking-ensure-fruit-safe-221920114.html|title=Farmers' drastic new plan to find needles in sabotaged strawberries|access-date=2018-09-18|language=en-AU|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180918004305/https://au.news.yahoo.com/drastic-new-measures-strawberry-farmers-taking-ensure-fruit-safe-221920114.html|archive-date=2018-09-18|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
=== Arrest === On 11 November 2018, My Ut Trinh, a 50-year-old farm supervisor, was arrested in Brisbane and charged with seven counts of contaminating goods, relating to one of the initial cases of contamination involving the Berry Licious brand.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Strawberry needle contamination scare: Queensland woman charged after months-long investigation |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-11-11/strawberry-needle-scare-woman-arrested-in-queensland/10486418 |work=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |location= |date=11 November 2018|access-date=12 November 2018}}</ref> Ms Trinh, who was born in Vietnam but came to Australia as a refugee 20 years ago by boat, worked at the Berrylicious/Berry Obsession fruit farm north of Brisbane as a picking supervisor.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/strawberry-needles-accused-my-ut-trinh-acted-in-spite-court-hears/news-story/d4350b399c0f5f606cdc86cb5449a917|title=Strawberry needles accused My Ut Trinh ‘acted in spite’, court hears|last=Peel|first=Charlie|date=13 November 2018|website=The Australian|publisher=News Corp Australia|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=15 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.news.com.au/national/queensland/police-arrest-woman-over-strawberry-contamination/news-story/fbe4e890572060b129c6c100a2fcca62|title=Strawberry accused motivated by ‘revenge’|work=NewsComAu|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref>
==Related incidents==
On 17 September 2018, a 62-year-old woman suffering from a mental illness was cautioned after she allegedly contaminated a banana with a metal object at a supermarket in [[Maryborough, Queensland]]. Queensland Police stated the incident was not linked to the contamination crisis.<ref>{{cite news |last=Bedo |first=Stephanie |date=17 September 2018 |title=Metal allegedly found in banana an 'isolated' incident |url=https://www.sunshinecoastdaily.com.au/news/police-investigating-after-metal-object-found-in-a/3523580/ |work=[[Sunshine Coast Daily]] |location= |access-date=18 September 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180918092534/https://www.sunshinecoastdaily.com.au/news/police-investigating-after-metal-object-found-in-a/3523580/ |archive-date=2018-09-18 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
On 18 September 2018, [[New South Wales Police]] announced needles had been discovered in bananas and apples in two separate incidents in the Sydney area. Detective superintendent Daniel Doherty reminded the public of the importance to report incidents of contamination and "to be vigilant and exercise caution when buying strawberries and other fruit in NSW." Doherty confimed police were investigating "more than 20 incidents in New South Wales, but nationally, the number is much higher."<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Police confirm 'isolated' incidents of apple and banana contamination |url=https://www.9news.com.au/2018/09/18/14/39/strawberries-contamination-crisis-apple-and-banana-cases-found-nsw |work=[[Nine News]] |location= |date=18 September 2018 |access-date=18 September 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180918083712/https://www.9news.com.au/2018/09/18/14/39/strawberries-contamination-crisis-apple-and-banana-cases-found-nsw |archive-date=2018-09-18 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> The apple was part of a pack of six, purchased from a Woolworths at [[The Ponds, New South Wales|The Ponds]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Reddie |first=Mark |date=18 September 2018 |title=Shopper claims she found needle in apple from Sydney supermarket |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-18/claims-needle-found-inside-apple-sold-at-sydney-woolworths/10264396 |work=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |location= |access-date=18 September 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180918163319/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-18/claims-needle-found-inside-apple-sold-at-sydney-woolworths/10264396 |archive-date=2018-09-18 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
On 20 September 2018, [[New South Wales Police]] reported that a young boy had been arrested after admitting to hiding sewing needles in strawberries as part of what police consider to be "a prank".<ref name=osborne>{{cite web |last1=Osborne |first1=Samuel |title=Strawberry needle contamination: Young boy arrested after admitting to spiking Australian fruit |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/australasia/australia-strawberries-needles-recalled-boy-arrested-needle-latest-update-a8544561.html |website=Independent |accessdate=20 September 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180919150156/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/australasia/australia-strawberries-needles-recalled-boy-arrested-needle-latest-update-a8544561.html |archive-date=2018-09-19 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> The current penalty in [[New South Wales]] for the deliberate contamination of food is up to 10 years in jail, however Australia's [[Prime Minister]] [[Scott Morrison]] has stated that "the government plans to increase the maximum jail term to 15 years.<ref name=osborne/>
Also on 20 September, a customer in [[West Gosford, New South Wales|West Gosford]] on the New South Wales [[Central Coast (New South Wales)|Central Coast]] discovered a needle inside a [[mango]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/09/19/australia/australia-strawberry-sabotage-needles-intl/index.html|title=Needle found in mango in latest chapter of Australia fruit crisis|last=CNN|first=Euan McKirdy, Ben Westcott and Simon Cullen,|work=CNN|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.perthnow.com.au/lifestyle/food/strawberry-needle-crisis-needle-found-in-coles-mango-by-customer-ng-b88967084z|title=Needle found in Coles mango|date=2018-09-20|work=PerthNow|access-date=2018-10-08|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.news.com.au/lifestyle/food/food-warnings/woolworths-stepping-up-attempts-to-stop-strawberry-sabotage-in-its-stores/news-story/2c99763b8f769c1b7b74aa04d2c99336|title=Woolies pulls sewing needles off shelves|work=NewsComAu|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref>
On 11 November 2018, [[Newshub]] announced that a 50 year old woman in Auckland, New Zealand, was arrested for contaminating strawberries with needles. In the wake of the needle crisis, Foodstuffs NZ made the decision to halt the distribution of Australian strawberries in all their stores including New World, Pak'nSave and Four Square. Countdown said that strawberries grown in New Zealand had not been affected, but it was in contact with New Zealand and Australian authorities.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newshub.co.nz/home/world/2018/11/50yo-woman-arrested-for-strawberry-needle-contamination.html|title=50yo woman arrested over strawberry needle contamination|work=Newshub|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Food safety in Australia]]
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Use British English|date=December 2017}} {{for|the American football player and U.S. Army general|Alexander Garfield Gillespie}} [[File:Gillespie 1810 PresBook.jpg|thumb]] '''Alexander Gillespie''' [[FRSE]], FRCSEd (21 March 1776 – 1 September 1859) was a Scottish surgeon. He is one of the few persons to have served two non-consecutive periods as President of the [[Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh]]. He was President from 1810 to 1812 and again from 1818 to 1820.
==Early life and education== Alexander Gillespie was born in Ayr, the son of Dr Thomas Gillespie, an Ayrshire physician, and his wife Jean Gillespie (née Thomson).<ref>Scotland's People. Old Parish Registers births, 578/40178 Ayr https://www.scotlandspeople.gov.uk/view-image/nrs_opr_records/3773706?image=178</ref> He became a Licentiate of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh in 1794 and a Fellow in 1803.<ref>Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh. (1874). List of Fellows of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh from ... 1581 to ... 1873. Edinburgh.</ref>
He obtained the degree of MD from the [[University of St Andrews Medical School]] in 1822, some 28 years after he began to practise medicine. This was common practice at this time with the St Andrews degrees being conferred on the basis of a written testimonial and payment of a fee, without the need for the candidate visiting St Andrews<ref>Shepherd, JA. Medical Teaching in St. Andrews University 1413-1972. British Medical Journal, 1972;3:38-41. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1788514/pdf/brmedj02211-0050.pdf </ref> Like many practitioners of his day he combined surgery with general practice. He had appointments as surgeon to a number of institutions including the Lock Hospital in Surgeons' Square, the Edinburgh Lunatic Asylum and Gillespie's Hospital for the Elderly.<ref>Medical Directory for Scotland, London, John Churchill, 1859 p31.</ref> He was surgeon to Donaldson's Hospital, a school which had family connections. His sister Jane Gillespie (1770–1828)<ref>The Edinburgh Magazine, Or Literary Miscellany,(1792) Edinburgh. Volume 16 p 359. https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=B183AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA350&lpg=PA350&q=jane+gillespie+donaldson+edinburgh&source=bl&ots=4snJR2Iur5&sig=dg6q98J64G1fxIwx7iWnbKbdAAM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjM3sPJgcHXAhUD2RoKHXTFDUoQ6AEIVTAO#v=onepage&q=jane%20gillespie%20donaldson%20edinburgh&f=false</ref> married [[James Donaldson (publisher)|James Donaldson]] (1751–1830), who bequeathed a large part of his estate to establish [[Donaldson's Hospital]], founded to maintain and educate poor children.<ref>Hogg, James. (ed) ''Donaldson's Hospital'' in Titan: a monthly magazine.Edinburgh, James Hogg, Vol 4, 1850. p103. https://play.google.com/books/reader?id=i7ERAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&output=reader&hl=en_GB&pg=GBS.PP103</ref> There is an insight into Alexander Gillespie's practice in his son's obituary which observes that Alexander Gillespie 'worked his easy largely aristocratic practice with a light hand...'<ref>Obituary. Dr James Donaldson Gillespie. Edinburgh Medical Journal. January 1892 p674</ref>
==Membership of societies== In 1806 he is listed as a member of the Royal Highland Agricultural Society.<ref>Medical Directory for Scotland, London, John Churchill, 1859 p31.</ref> In 1812 he was elected a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]]. His proposers were [[Thomas Allan]], [[James Russell (surgeon)|James Russell]] and [[Ninian Imrie]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp1.pdf}}</ref>
==Later life and family== In 1818 he was living at 30 York Place in [[New Town, Edinburgh|Edinburgh's New Town]], a handsome Georgian terraced townhouse. Post Office Directories continue to show him here for many years but his given occupation changes from surgeon to doctor in 1834, suggesting that he had given up surgery in favour of general practice.<ref>Edinburgh and Leith Post Office Directories 1818 to 1850</ref>
He died in Edinburgh on 1 September 1859 at 45 Castle Street and is buried in [[Dalry, Edinburgh|Dalry Cemetery]].<ref>Scotland's People Statutory Register of deaths 1859 652/2411 https://www.scotlandspeople.gov.uk/view-image/nrs_stat_deaths/298042</ref>
On 1 June 1812 he had married Eliza Mary Shirriff. <ref>Scots Magazine 1812, Vol 75, p478.https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=cT4zAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA478&lpg=PA478&dq=Eliza+Mary+Shiriff&source=bl&ots=GHFa_AGi5G&sig=JLeZuuTi6oc-Tc0gVXwb8zjyTZY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiur_eXysHXAhVDFMAKHSERBccQ6AEILDAB#v=onepage&q=Eliza%20Mary%20Shiriff&f=false </ref> Their son, James Donaldson Gillespie (1824-1891) graduated MD from the University of Edinburgh, gained the FRCSEd diploma, became a surgeon in the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh and was President of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh between 1869 and 1871.<ref>Obituary. Dr James Donaldson Gillespie. Edinburgh Medical Journal. January 1892 p674</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gillespie, Alexander}} [[Category:1776 births]] [[Category:1859 deaths]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Scottish surgeons]] [[Category:Presidents of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of St Andrews]] [[Category:19th-century Scottish medical doctors]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} {{Use British English|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox Organization |name = Association of Mental Health Providers |image = Association_of_Mental_Health_Providers_logo.png |image_border = |size = 125px |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |motto = The leading representative body for voluntary and community sector mental health organisations in England and Wales |formation = 2005 as Mental Health Providers Forum; relaunched in May 2017 as Association of Mental Health Providers |extinction = |type = [[non-governmental organization|non-governmental organisation]] |status = [[charitable organization|registered charity]] |purpose = |headquarters = [[London]] |location = 3rd Floor, 54 Baker Street, London, W1U 7BU |region_served =[[England]] and [[Wales]] |membership = Voluntary and community sector mental health service providers |language = |leader_title = Chief Executive |leader_name = Kathy Roberts |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_volunteers = |website = {{url|https://amhp.org.uk/}} |remarks = }}The '''Association of Mental Health Providers''', known until May 2017 as '''Mental Health Providers Forum''' (MHPF),{{Cite web |url=https://amhp.org.uk/announcement-of-relaunch/ |title=Announcement of Relaunch |date=19 May 2017 |publisher=Association of Mental Health Providers|accessdate = 27 May 2017}} is a [[charitable organization|registered charity]] based in London It is registered in [[England]] with the [[Charity Commission]] as Voluntary Sector Mental Health Providers Forum, charity 1120222.
{{cite web | url=http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Showcharity/RegisterOfCharities/CharityWithoutPartB.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=1120222&SubsidiaryNumber=0 | title=Voluntary Sector Mental Health Providers Forum | publisher=[[Charity Commission]] | work=Charity overview | accessdate=30 December 2014}} and the representative body for [[voluntary sector|voluntary]] and [[Community organization|community sector]] [[mental health]] organisations in [[England and Wales]], working nationally and regionally to influence practice and policy. It aims to improve the range and quality of [[community mental health services|mental health services]] by increasing the involvement of the voluntary sector in delivering them, working in partnership with the wider sector and government agencies. Specific projects include the promotion of innovation in the sector, evidencing best practice to achieve the best outcomes for individuals and supporting [[Recovery model|recovery]]. The Association leads a collaboration of voluntary mental health organisations including the [[Centre for Mental Health]], National Survivor User Network for Mental Health (NSUN), the [[Mental Health Foundation]], [[Mind (charity)|Mind]] and [[Rethink Mental Illness]] in the VCSE Health and Wellbeing Alliance with the [[Department of Health]], [[NHS England]] and [[Public Health England]]. The Association's membership consists of voluntary sector organisations providing mental health services in England. The current Chief Executive (since April 2012) is Kathy Roberts,{{cite web|url=https://amhp.org.uk/about-us/staff/kathy-roberts/|title=Kathy Roberts|publisher=Association of Mental Health Providers|accessdate= 24 June 2017}} who has a background in [[Health and Social Care|health and social care]] and the voluntary and community sector. She succeeded Dr Ian McPherson, previously Director of the [[National Mental Health Development Unit]]. The first Chief Executive of the Forum was Judy Weleminsky{{cite news | url=http://www.thirdsector.co.uk/news/619676/ | title=Forum launched to assist work with mental health | work=Third Sector | date=30 November 2005 | accessdate=16 February 2015 | author= Pati, Anita|location=London}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dwp.gov.uk/docs/hwwb-working-our-way-to-better-mental-health.pdf|archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20130128102031/http://www.dwp.gov.uk/docs/hwwb-working-our-way-to-better-mental-health.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=28 January 2013|publisher= [[HMSO]]|title=Working our way to better mental health: a framework for action|date=December 2009|isbn= 978-0-10-177562-5|accessdate = 16 February 2015}} who led the organisation from December 2005 to January 2011. The Association has increased its work to bring the views of mental health service providers into national policy and strategy discussions, working closely with members to inform and implement the 2011 [https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/213761/dh_124058.pdf ''No health without mental health''] cross-government mental health strategy. An area of focus from 2014 has been housing provision for people with mental health needs. In September 2014 AMHP published a report outlining successful housing models{{cite web | url=https://www.housinglin.org.uk/_assets/Resources/Housing/OtherOrganisation/housingreport_3.pdf | title=Housing Models: Examples of Innovative Practice and Design | publisher=Mental Health Providers Forum | date=September 2014 | accessdate=9 December 2017 | author=Chapman, Ian}} and a national forum is now established. ==Mental Health Recovery Star== In 2008 The Association, with Triangle Consulting, worked with [[Mental health consumer|service users]] and The Association's members to develop the Mental Health Recovery Star,{{cite web | url=http://www.outcomesstar.org.uk/using-the-star/see-the-stars/recovery-star/ | title=Recovery Star: The Outcomes Star for adults managing their mental health | publisher=Triangle Consulting Social Enterprise Limited | accessdate=9 December 2017}} which was recommended by the [[Department of Health (United Kingdom)|Department of Health]] [[New Horizons (strategy)|New Horizons]] programme and has been developed for use in adult mental health services. The Recovery Star is a [[Care Programme Approach|key-working]] tool that enables staff to support individuals they work with to understand their recovery and plot their progress. It is also an outcomes tool that enables organisations to measure and assess the effectiveness of the services they deliver.{{cite journal | title=Recovery Star: validating user recovery | author=Dickens, G., Onifade, Y., Sugarman, P. and Weleminsky, J. | journal=The Psychiatrist | year=2012 | volume=36 | issue=2 | pages=45–50 | issn=0955-6036 | doi=10.1192/pb.bp.111.034264|url=http://pb.rcpsych.org/content/36/2/45|accessdate= 13 February 2016}}{{cite web | url=http://mentalhealthpartnerships.com/resource/recovery-star/ | title=Recovery Star | publisher=Mental Health Partnerships | accessdate=24 June 2017}} It is now being used by many [[mental health trust]]s in England.{{cite web | url=http://www.humber.nhs.uk/about-our-trust/recovery-star.htm | title=Recovery Star | publisher=[[Humber NHS Foundation Trust]] | work=About our Trust | accessdate=9 December 2017}}{{cite web | url=http://www.awp.nhs.uk/advice-support/service-users/care-planning/ | title=Recovery Star | publisher=[[Avon and Wiltshire Mental Health Partnership NHS Trust]] | work=Advice & Support: Service users, carers and families | accessdate=13 September 2016}} ==See also== *[[Community Sector Coalition]] *[[Improving Access to Psychological Therapies]] *[[Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services]] '''Other UK mental health charities:''' *[[Centre for Mental Health]] *[[Mental Health Foundation]] *[[Mind (charity)|Mind]] *[[Rethink Mental Illness]] *[[Richmond Fellowship]] *[[SANE (charity)|SANE]] *[[Together: Working for Well-being]] *[[Turning Point (charity)]] '''General:''' * [[Mental health in the United Kingdom]] ==Notes== {{reflist|group="nb"}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== *{{cite journal | title=Recovery Star: validating user recovery | author=Dickens, G., Onifade, Y., Sugarman, P. and Weleminsky, J. | journal=The Psychiatrist | year=2012 | volume=36 | issue=2 | pages=45–50 | issn=0955-6036 | doi=10.1192/pb.bp.111.034264|url=http://pb.rcpsych.org/content/36/2/45}} ==External links== *[https://amhp.org.uk/ Official website] {{Infobox lake | name = Bratsk Reservoir | image = Wasserkraftwerk-Bratsk.jpg | caption = | image_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | location = [[Irkutsk Oblast]] | coords = {{coord|56|15|N|101|45|E|region:RU-IRK_type:waterbody|display=inline,title}} | type = [[Hydroelectricity|Hydroelectric]] [[reservoir]] | inflow = [[Angara River]] | outflow = [[Angara River]] | catchment = | basin_countries = Russia | length = | width = | area = {{convert|5470|km2}} | depth = | max-depth = | volume = {{convert|169.27|km3|acre.ft|abbr=on}} | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = | frozen = | islands = | cities = }} '''Bratsk Reservoir''' ({{lang-ru|Бра́тское водохрани́лище}}, ''Bratskoye Reservoir'') is a [[reservoir (water)|reservoir]] on the [[Angara River]], located in [[Irkutsk Oblast]],<ref>Partly in the [[Ust-Orda Buryat Okrug]]</ref> [[Russia]]. It is named after the city of [[Bratsk]], the largest city adjacent to the reservoir. It has a surface area of {{convert|5470|km2}} and a maximum volume of 169.27 × 10<sup>12</sup> litres (37.2 × 10<sup>12</sup> gallons).<ref name="GSE">''[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]]'', entry on [http://dict.yandex.ru/art.xml?art=bse/00010/11400.htm&encpage=bse&mrkp=http%3A//hghltd.yandex.com/yandbtm%3Furl%3Dhttp%253A//encycl.yandex.ru/texts/bse/00010/11400.htm%26text%3D%25E1%25F0%25E0%25F2%25F1%25EA%25EE%25E5%2B%25E2%25EE%25E4%25EE%25F5%25F0%25E0%25ED%25E8%25EB%25E8%25F9%25E5%26reqtext%3D%2528%25E1%25F0%25E0%25F2%25F1%25EA%25EE%25E5%253A%253A235820%2B%2526%2B%25E2%25EE%25E4%25EE%25F5%25F0%25E0%25ED%25E8%25EB%25E8%25F9%25E5%253A%253A349237%2529//6%26%26isu%3D2 Братское водохранилище]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The [[concrete]] dam of the [[Bratsk hydroelectric plant]] was completed in 1967. It is {{convert|125|m|ft|0}} high and {{convert|4417|m|ft|0}} long. The [[Baikal Amur Mainline]] railroad runs along the top of the dam. At the time of its inauguration, the reservoir was the [[Artificial lake#List of reservoirs by volume|largest artificial lake]] in the world.<ref>George St. George. ''Siberia: The New Frontier''. D. McKay Co, 1969. Page 147.</ref> Its electrical power capacity is 4,500 [[Watt#Megawatt|MW]].<ref name="GSE" />
==In literature== The epic construction of the Bratsk Dam is the subject of a large eponymous poem by [[Yevgeny Yevtushenko]]. Much later (1976), the impact of the reservoir construction on the life of the villagers upstream, many of whom had to be relocated from the flooded areas, or lost some the best lands of their collective farms, became the motive of [[Valentin Rasputin]]'s novel ''Farewell to Matyora''. <ref>{{citation |first=Valentin Grigorʹevich |last=Rasputin |publisher=Northwestern University Press |year=1995 |isbn=0-8101-1329-5 |title=Farewell to Matyora |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=pJbPaapDI4kC |page=ix |section=Foreword (by Kathleen Parthé)}} (Translated by [[Antonina W. Bouis]])</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://lkirchner.de/kodar/kodar.html Description and photo]

{{Infobox organization | image = Cas EN COLOUR hiresforweb.jpg | formation = 1988 | type = Registered Charity | headquarters = Ottawa, ON | language = English, French | key_people = Gary Lacasse (Executive Director) Greg Riehl (President) | name = Canadian AIDS Society | abbreviation = CAS | website = cdnaids.ca | location = 170 Laurier West #602, Ottawa, ON }}
The '''Canadian AIDS Society''' (CAS) is a national coalition of community-based [[AIDS service organization]]s across [[Canada]]. Registered as a charity since 1988, CAS has a mandate to improve the response to [[HIV/AIDS in Canada]] across all sectors of society, and to support people and communities living with HIV/AIDS.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://apps.cra-arc.gc.ca/ebci/haip/srch/t3010form22quickview-eng.action?&fpe=2017-03-31&b=120863311RR0001|title=Canadian Revenue Agency's Charity Listing|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-20}}</ref>
== History == ===Establishment=== CAS was established after the first two national conferences on HIV/AIDS in Montreal (1985) and Toronto (1986) to act as a national umbrella organization for AIDS service organizations in Canada.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdnaids.ca/about-us/history/|title=History of Canadian AIDS Society|last=|first=|date=|website=Canadian AIDS Society|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-12}}</ref> The original founding member organizations were:
* AIDS Calgary Awareness Association * AIDS Committee of London * AIDS Committee of Ottawa * AIDS Committee of Thunder Bay * AIDS Committee of Toronto * AIDS Committee of Windsor * AIDS Network of Edmonton * AIDS Regina * AIDS Saskatoon *[[AIDS Vancouver]] * AIDS Vancouver Island * Comité sida aide Montréal (C-SAM) * Metro Area Committee on AIDS (Halifax) * Newfoundland and Labrador AIDS Association * Winnepeg Gay Community Health Centre
Before CAS became a registered charitable organization with paid staff in Ottawa in 1988, a voluntary secretariat steered the organization operating out of the AIDS Network of Edmonton office.
==Objective== CAS's objective is to strengthen the response to HIV/AIDS in Canada and enrich the lives of people and communities living with, and affected by, HIV/AIDS.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdnaids.ca/about-us/|title=About us - Canadian AIDS Society|website=www.cdnaids.ca|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-24}}</ref>
== Structure== ===Member Organizations=== CAS represents AIDS service organizations across Canada in almost every Province. A full list of member organizations is available on CAS's website.[https://www.cdnaids.ca/members/]
===National Partners=== CAS collaborates with other nationally-focused organizations the address HIV/AIDS in Canada. These partners include:
* Canadian Association for HIV Research (CAHR) * Canadian Public Health Association (CPHA) * Interagency Coalition on AIDS and Development (ICAD) * [[Canadian HIV/AIDS Legal Network]] * realize (formerly CWGHR) * CATIE * CTAC * Canadian Aboriginal AIDS Network * CIHR Canadian HIV Trials Network
=== Governance === CAS is governed by a board of directors that includes two representatives from each region of Canada, one of whom must by HIV-positive. Additionally, CAS has two at-large board of director seats for one man and one woman to ensure gender diverse representation at the board level. There is also one board of director seat reserved for an HIV-positive young person.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdnaids.ca/contact-us/board-of-directors/|title=Board of Directors - Canadian AIDS Society|last=|first=|date=|website=Canadian AIDS Society|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-12}}</ref> ===Funding=== CAS has historically been funded by the Federal government through [[Health Canada]] and/or the [[Public Health Agency of Canada]], however since the [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberals]] reorganized funding priorities for HIV and Hepatitis-C in 2016 CAS has received no federal funding.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ipolitics.ca/2018/04/24/dozens-of-hiv-aids-organizations-struggling-from-lost-funding/|title=Dozens of HIV/AIDS organizations struggling from lost funding - iPolitics|date=2018-04-24|work=iPolitics|access-date=2018-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> This change in funding, and the general under-funding of HIV/AIDS service organizations in Canada more broadly, resulted in sharp criticism of the Liberal government, particularly by CAS's national partner, the [[Canadian HIV/AIDS Legal Network]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aidslaw.ca/site/download/16731/|title=The Missing Millions: Stopping and Reversing the Steady Erosion of Federal HIV Funding|last=Elliot|first=Richard|date=|website=Canadian HIV/AIDS Legal Network|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-24}}</ref>
== Notable Programs and Campaigns ==
===AIDS Awareness Week & World AIDS Day=== From 1991-2001 CAS ran an annual AIDS Awareness Week campaign with support from various governmental, corporate, and charitable organizations including [[Health Canada|Health and Welfare Canada]], the [[Public Health Agency of Canada]], the [[Canadian Hemophilia Society]], [[Levi Strauss & Co.|Levi Strauss & Co]]., and others. AIDS Awareness Week took place in October, but after this project came to an end when the [[Public Health Agency of Canada]] stopped funding for it, CAS's awareness campaigns largely revolved around [[World AIDS Day]] of each year. Each year's AIDS Awareness Week campaign, was organized around a theme. Ads were often developed by [[Ottawa]] creative agency [[McMillan (agency)|McMillan]] and appeared in wide-circulation magazines and periodicals including [[MacLean's]], [[L'actualité]], and [[The Globe and Mail]].<ref name="Reuters">{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUS121769+01-Dec-2008+MW20081201| title=Reuters| accessdate=2009-02-13 | date=2008-12-01}}</ref> ===[https://quilt.ca AIDS Memorial Quilt]=== The Canadian AIDS Memorial Quilt was a project initiated by AIDS activists in [[Halifax, Nova Scotia|Halifax, NS]] who organized a tour of the American [[NAMES Project AIDS Memorial Quilt|AIDS Memorial Quilt]] throughout Canada in 1989 which resulted in the creation of hundreds of Canadian quilt panels.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.grandriver-rainbowhistory.ca/tri-PrideEvents/2003tri-Pride/2003-06-12-15CanadianAIDSMemorialQuiltProgramme.pdf|title=The Canadian AIDS Memorial Quilt Event Brochure|last=The NAMES project - Canada|first=|date=2003-06-12|website=Grand River Rainbow Historical Project|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In 1992, the activists that began the project passed stewardship of the quilt onto CAS, but in 1994 The NAMES project | le projet des NOMS - Canada was established with Lawrence Eisener as the founding Executive Director.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ic.gc.ca/app/scr/cc/CorporationsCanada/fdrlCrpDtls.html?corpId=3040372|title=Federal Corporation Information - 304037-2 - Online Filing Centre - Corporations Canada - Corporations - Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada|website=www.ic.gc.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-10-22}}</ref> John Mactavish and John Stinson were also involved in the establishing of the organization which took over stewardship of the quilt.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://winnipegsun.com/2015/10/17/20-questions-with-john-stinson/wcm/37d358f1-37bc-48b4-8e27-ab40f613cadf|title=20 Questions with John Stinson|date=2015-10-17|work=Winnipeg Sun|access-date=2018-10-22|language=en-US}}</ref> The NAMES project - Canada maintained and grew the quilt from 400 panels in 1993 to over 600 panels today.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/aids-quilt-canada-1.4622347|title=AIDS group mulls how to preserve a Canadian quilt {{!}} CBC News|work=CBC|access-date=2018-10-22|language=en-US}}</ref> The quilt was response to the AIDS epidemic affecting the country at the time. Central goals of the quilt were: 1) To commemorate the lives of Canadians who had died of AIDS-related illness(es); 2) to raise funds for community-based [[AIDS service organization]]. In 2013 The NAMES project - Canada dissolved and once again CAS became the steward of the quilt.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aidsmemorial.info/memorial/id=39/canadian_aids_memorial_quilt.html|title=AIDSmemorial.info - Canadian AIDS Memorial Quilt|last=|first=|date=|website=www.aidsmemorial.info|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-22}}</ref> A new digital version of the quilt was launched by CAS in 2018 and is available online at quilt.ca.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://aidsactivisthistory.ca/2018/02/13/the-canadian-aids-memorial-quilt-website-launch/|title=The Canadian AIDS Memorial Quilt: Website Launch!|date=2018-02-13|work=AIDS Activist History Project|access-date=2018-10-22|language=en-US}}</ref>
===AIDS walk=== Since 1988,Canadian AIDS Society participate in numerous walks to raise money for the organization and to raise awareness on HIV/AIDS.
===[http://hivtestingday.ca/ National HIV Testing Day]=== On June 27, 2017 CAS launched a national initiative to encourage people to be tested for HIV. Over forty community organizations participated across all regions of Canada by offering free HIV tests to anyone who wanted one.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/4286443/canadian-aids-society-year-launching-national-hiv-testing-day/|title=Canadian AIDS Society lives to see another year, launching national ‘HIV testing day’|last=Britneff|first=Beatrice|date=|website=Globe and Mail|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-12}}</ref> National Testing Day in Canada, much like its [[National HIV Testing Day (United States)|American counterpart]] that was established in 1995, encourages the use of [[Diagnosis of HIV/AIDS|Point-of-Care Testing (POCT)]] where participants can get their results in a few minutes as opposed two-weeks later.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdnaids.ca/testing/|title=HIV Testing Day - Canadian AIDS Society|website=www.cdnaids.ca|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-22}}</ref> A 2016 study on the efficacy of National Testing Day in the United States indicates that the program successfully tested more people from priority populations and identified more previously undiagnosed HIV-positive people than during control weeks.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.catie.ca/en/pc/evidence-briefs/nhtd|title=National HIV Testing Day|last=|first=|date=|website=CAITE|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-22}}</ref>
==Publications== Listed below are some of the Canadian AIDS Society’s publications in chronological order. They include historical research, medical studies, tool kits, community involvement resources, and reports. The older publications are linked for historical reference and up to date research should always be consulted.

* [https://www.cdnaids.ca/trans-toolkit-practical-resources-community-based-organizations/ The Trans* Toolkit: Practical Resources for Community- Based Organizations]
=== 2014 ===

* [https://www.cdnaids.ca/wp-content/uploads/Rural-and-Remote-.pdf Rural and Remote Needs Assessment] * [https://www.cdnaids.ca/faith-based-organizations-addressing-hivaids-canada Faith - based Organization Addressing HIV/ AIDS in Canada] * [https://www.cdnaids.ca/wp-content/uploads/trans-needs-assessment-FINAL.pdf Trans Needs Assessment Report]
=== 2013 ===
* [https://www.cdnaids.ca/wp-content/uploads/HIV_Transmission_Factors_that_Affect_Biological_Risk.pdf HIV Transmission: Factors that affect biological risk] * [https://www.cdnaids.ca/wp-content/uploads/One-Foot-Forward-Mod-10.pdf One Foot Forwards: A GIPA Training Toolkit, Module 10]

* [https://www.cdnaids.ca/women-hiv-testing-canada-barriers-recommendations-identified-service-providers/ Women and HIV testing in Canada: Barriers and Recommendation as identified by service providers] * [https://www.cdnaids.ca/positive-prevention-information-sheet-series/ Young Gay Mans information sheet] * [https://www.cdnaids.ca/wp-content/uploads/One-Foot-Forward-Mod-8.pdf ONe foot Forwards: A GIPA Training Toolkit, module 8] * [https://www.cdnaids.ca/wp-content/uploads/One-Foot-Forward-Mod-9.pdf One Foot Forwards: a GIPA Training toolkit, module 9]
=== 2011 ===
* [https://www.cdnaids.ca/wp-content/uploads/More-than-just-rolling-up-your-sleeves.pdf More than just rolling up your sleeves: and HIV preparedness kit] * [https://www.cdnaids.ca/wp-content/uploads/Follow-the-condoms-and-Needles.pdf Follow the Condoms and needles: What previous public health interventions teach us about future deployment of HIV Vaccine] * [http://www.cdnaids.ca/wp-content/uploads/Economic-Cost-of-HIV-AIDS-in-Canada.pdf The economic cost of HIV/AIDS in Canada]

* [http://www.cdnaids.ca/wp-content/uploads/Positive-Prevention-Towards-a-Pan-Canadian-Framework.pdf Positive Prevention: Towards a Pan- Canadian Framework] * [https://www.cdnaids.ca/wp-content/uploads/Knowledge-is-our-best-defence-HIV-curriculum-2010.pdf Knowledge is our best defence: An HIV/ AIDS Education Resource for Canadian School (curriculum)] * [https://www.cdnaids.ca/wp-content/uploads/Knowledge-is-our-best-defence-HIV-curriculum-RESOURCES-2010.pdf Knowledge is our best defence: An HIV/ AIDS Education Resource for Canadian Schools (teacher resources)] * [https://www.cdnaids.ca/enhancing-capacity-to-provide-services-for-people-who-use-substances-a-needs-and-assets-assessment/ Enhancing Capacity to Provide services for people who Use Substances: A needs and Assets Assessment] * [https://www.cdnaids.ca/wp-content/uploads/One-Foot-Forward-Facilitators-Guide.pdf One foot Forwards: A GIPA training toolkit, facilitator’s guide] * [https://www.cdnaids.ca/wp-content/uploads/HIV-and-housing.pdf HIV and Housing: Towards a National housing Strategy] * [https://www.cdnaids.ca/wp-content/uploads/PrEP-Kit.pdf PrEP Community advocates Community Mobilization kit]

'''Community Options, Inc. ''' is a 501(c)3 national nonprofit organization.<ref>[http://www.pvo.net/usaid/pvo.asp?i=3043&INCVOLAG=YES&INCSUM=YES&VolagText= USAID " Registered U.S. and International PVOs"] "USAID", 2013</ref> that provides housing and employment supports <ref>[https://www.disability.gov/resource/community-options/ "Find organizations in your community"] " Disability.gov", 2014</ref> to people with [[Intellectual disability|intellectual disabilities]], [[developmental disabilities]] and [[traumatic brain injury]]. The organizations headquarters are located in Princeton, NJ. In 2015 Community Options was named the fourth-largest nonprofit organization based in New Jersey.<ref>Danielle Mack, [http://www.njbiz.com/section/listcentral?djoPage=view_html&djoPid=9913 " NEW JERSEY'S TOP Nonprofit Organizations"], ''NJBIZ'', 2013</ref>
==History == The organization was founded in 1989 by Robert Stack, the President and CEO, along with a small group of [[List of disability rights activists|disability advocates]] to create residential and employment supports for individuals with disabilities. In 2008 the organization supported over 1,400 people with disabilities.<ref>Dilshanie Perera, [http://www.towntopics.com/jul3008/other3.php "Princeton Resident Named to Gov. Richardson’s Task Force"], ''Town Topics'', Wednesday, 30 July 2008</ref> Community Options, Inc. also advocates for the [[Deinstitutionalization|de-institutionalization movement]]. The organization states that all people with disabilities should live in community-based settings and be released from out-of-state-run institutions <ref>Matt Hammond, [http://www.nj.com/mercer/index.ssf/2012/10/hopewell_to_break_ground_for_g.html "Hopewell to break ground for group home"], "The Times", 21 October 2012</ref>
Robert Stack was born in McKeesport, Pennsylvania in 1955. He attended St. Fidelis Seminary in Butler, Pennsylvania for the priesthood. During this time, he volunteered to work with children with significant disabilities every Saturday and Wednesday afternoon. He dropped out of the Seminary and after graduating from the University of Dayton (Dayton, Ohio), went to Kent State (Kent, Ohio) to study Philosophy. In 1979 he left to work for the State of New York at the Suffolk Developmental Center as a Recreational Aid in the institution. He opened the first two state-operated group homes on the grounds of the institution. He was hired as the Executive Assistant to the Director of the Division of Mental Retardation in 1981. He wrote the original white paper converting the Division of Mental Retardation to the Division of Developmental Disabilities. It was the first time New Jersey government recognized Autism as a treatable and fundable disability.
Stack was youngest Executive Director of United Cerebral Palsy for the entire state in 1984. He founded UCP of Mercer (now enable) UCP of Morris and UPC of Atlantic and Cape May County. He was appointed as the Deputy Director over all the institutions for NJ by Eddie C. Moore in 1987. Stack closed the first institution in New Jersey in Middlesex County.
After the death of Eddie Moore, Stack became a consultant and in 1988 formed an exploratory group to look at the lack of services for people with significant disabilities in NJ, Texas, NY, PA and Tennessee. He incorporated Community Options with friends from both University of Dayton and Kent State in 1989. In 1990 Stack introduced John F. Kennedy Jr. to the Rehabilitation Conference participants for over 2,000 in Albany, New York.
In 1992, Community Options opened their first four group homes in New Jersey. From 1995 to 2011, group homes were opened in six other states including Pennsylvania, Texas, New York, South Carolina, Kentucky and Tennessee.<ref>[http://www.comop.org/about-us/history/ "A Brief History of Community Options, Inc."] "Community Options, Inc.", 2014</ref> The New Jersey House of Representatives honored Community Options for their 25 years of service on February 10, 2014<ref>Hon. Rodney P. Frelinghuysen, [http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CREC-2014-02-10/html/CREC-2014-02-10-pt1-PgE189-3.htm "Celebrating The 25th Anniversary of Community Options"],"Congressional Record Volume 160 Number 24", 10 February 2014</ref> The 48th Governor of New Jersey [[Thomas Kean]] was honored by Community Options on May 8, 2014 with the presentation of The Betty Pendler Award for all his years of service dedicated to people with disabilities<ref>[http://www.nj.gov/humanservices/opmrdd/home/history/ "History"], "Office for Prevention of Developmental Disabilities", 2014</ref>
==Cupid’s Chase 5K == Cupid’s Chase 5K is an annual fundraising race presented by Community Options, Inc.<ref>Ambrose Salmini, [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MvAwVsU7HK0&list=UU5gBJeug96ESCdbPiuylQoA "2014 Cupid's Chase NYC "] "RUNNING Series", 5 March 2014</ref> It takes place every year on the Saturday of Valentine’s Day weekend. Cupid’s Chase 5K began in Princeton University’s Jadwin Gymnasium in 2009.<ref>[http://www.compuscore.com/cs2009/janfeb/cupid1.htm "CUPID'S CHASE 5K RUN Overall Results"] "compuscore", 14 February 2009</ref><ref>[http://www.princeton.edu/~run/races.html "Past Races"] "Princeton Running Club", 14 February 2009</ref> In 2014, Cupid’s Chase took place in 24 cities across the country.<ref>Matlin Smith, [http://www.lcsun-news.com/las_cruces-news/ci_25069806/cupids-chase-5k-benefits-nonprofit-community-option#sthash.sI1m3NKC.dpuf "Cupid's Chase 5K benefits nonprofit Community Option"] "The Las Cruces Sun-News ", 05 February 2014</ref>
==Services == Community Options operates several businesses in the United States that employs people with disabilities.<ref>[http://www.comop.org/services/enterprises/ " Enterprises "] "Community Options, Inc.", 2014</ref> Community Options opened ''Vaseful'', a nonprofit flower shop, in 1999. Employees are responsible for credit card processing, phone orders, shipping, distribution, inventory management and floral arranging.<ref>[http://newjersey.news12.com/multimedia/new-brunswick-s-vaseful-gets-ready-for-mother-s-day-1.7973518 "New Brunswick’s Vaseful gets ready for Mother’s Day"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20140820182959/http://newjersey.news12.com/multimedia/new-brunswick-s-vaseful-gets-ready-for-mother-s-day-1.7973518 |date=2014-08-20 }} "News 12 New Jersey", 9 May 2014</ref> In 2008, Community Options opened ''Presents of Mind'', a nonprofit gift store. Employees' duties include retail management, point-of-sale software, customer relations skills and store layout.<ref>PHIL GARBER, [http://newjerseyhills.com/mt_olive_chronicle/news/presents-of-mind-is-gift-to-disabled/article_5ea12c2a-2779-53b8-a02c-f0aa99b4f79a.html?mode=story "‘Presents of Mind’ is gift to disabled"] "Mount Olive Chronicle", 30 January 2009</ref> The ''Daily Plan It'' is an office and conference space for local businesses. Employees are responsible for customer service and facilities maintenance. The first Daily Plan It opened in Princeton, NJ in 1997.<ref>Brendan Kuty, [http://www.nj.com/morris/index.ssf/2013/10/video_the_daily_plan_it_in_morristown_teaches_job_skills_to_the_developmentally_disabled.html "The Daily Plan It in Morristown teaches job skills to the developmentally disabled"] "New Jersey On-Line", 14 October 2013</ref> Community Options and the ''Parents Group'' opened ''The Red Ribbon Academy'' in 2013. The Red Ribbon Academy medical day program provides medical, therapeutic and recreational supports to people with severe developmental disabilities.<ref>[http://www.njleg.state.nj.us/legislativepub/budget_2015/031314/Thomas_L.pdf "Testimony of Linda Zani Thomas of The Parents Group"] "New Jersey Legislature Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee Public Hearing" 13 March 2014</ref>
==iMatter Conference== Community Options hosts an annual national conference to discuss services to people with developmental disabilities and traumatic brain injury. Guest speakers in the past have included Jennifer Velez, [[Fran Harris]], [[Judy Woodruff]], [[Sean Stephenson]], Colleen Wieck and [[Louis Greenwald|Lou Greenwald]]. Topics include employment, business development, accessible housing, program development and employee hiring and retention.
==Betty Pendler Award== Each spring, Community Options selects a distinguished person who exemplifies the mission of Community Options as the Betty Pendler Award recipient. Betty Pendler was a member of the board of directors for the AHRC in New York City. Pendler was committed to people with disabilities, their families, and those who served them, in addition to raising a daughter with a developmental disability. Pendler died in 2001. Past recipients of the Betty Pendler Award are: Frank Zak (1991); Jane Olson (1992); Krystal Odell (1993); Karl Pfister (1994); Fran Curley (1995); Dan Fairchild (1996); David Norcross (1997); Patty Moore (1998); Peter Dulligan (1999); Madeleine Will (2000); Greg Hritz (2001); Bright Rajaratnam (2002); Mario Saenz (2003); Karen Hensley (2004); Matt Greller (2005); Reggie Shell (2006); Marge Brown (2007); Svetlana Repic-Qira (2008); Lisa Smith (2009); Jessica Guberman (2010); [[Joseph Kyrillos]] (2011); Christopher Dixon (2012); Brian Dion (2013); [[Thomas H. Kean]] (2014); Elaine Katz (2015); [[Robert M. Gordon|Robert]] and Gail Balph Gordon (2016); and [[Nikki Haley]] (2017).<ref>{{cite web|title=Ambassador Nikki Haley to Receive Community Options’ Betty Pendler Award at National Conference|url=https://www.comop.org/ambassador-nikki-haley-to-receive-community-options-betty-pendler-award-at-national-conference/|website=Community Options, Inc.|accessdate=27 December 2017|date=25 September 2017}}</ref>
