revision.comment: image is interesting, but quote is substantiated by the journal cite and not the image that comes from that same journal article
revision.text:
'''Prevention of mental disorders''' are measures that try to decrease the chances of a [[mental disorder]] occurring. A 2004 WHO report stated that "prevention of these disorders is obviously one of the most effective ways to reduce the [disease] burden."<ref>{{cite book |author1=World Health Organization, Department of Mental Health and Substance Abuse |author2=Prevention Research Centre of the Universities of Nijmegen and Maastricht |date=2004 |title=Prevention of mental disorders: effective interventions and policy options: summary report |publisher=World Health Organization |location=Geneva |isbn=92-4-159215-X |url=http://www.who.int/mental_health/evidence/en/prevention_of_mental_disorders_sr.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref> The 2011 [[European Psychiatric Association]] (EPA) guidance on prevention of mental disorders states "There is considerable evidence that various psychiatric conditions can be prevented through the implementation of effective evidence-based interventions."<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.eurpsy.2011.10.004 |title=European Psychiatric Association (EPA) guidance on prevention of mental disorders |year=2012 |last1=Campion |first1=J. |last2=Bhui |first2=K. |last3=Bhugra |first3=D. |journal=European Psychiatry |volume=27 |issue=2 |pages=68–80 |pmid=22285092 |last4=European Psychiatric |first4=Association}}</ref> A 2011 [[UK Department of Health]] report on the economic case for mental health promotion and mental illness prevention found that "many interventions are outstandingly good value for money, low in cost and often become self-financing over time, saving public expenditure".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www2.lse.ac.uk/businessAndConsultancy/LSEEnterprise/news/2011/healthstrategy.aspx |title=Mental health promotion and mental illness prevention: The economic case |publisher=London School of Economics and Political Science |date=2 February 2011 |accessdate=May 27, 2013}}</ref> In 2016, the [[National Institute of Mental Health]] re-affirmed prevention as a research priority area.<ref>https://www.nimh.nih.gov/about/strategic-planning-reports/strategic-research-priorities/srp-objective-3/index.shtml</ref>
==Methods==
===Parenting=== [[Parenting]] may affect the child's mental health,<ref name=pmid24308895>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.jad.2013.11.007 |pmid=24308895 |title=Parental factors associated with depression and anxiety in young people: A systematic review and meta-analysis |journal=Journal of Affective Disorders |volume=156 |pages=8–23 |year=2014 |last1=Yap |first1=Marie Bee Hui |last2=Pilkington |first2=Pamela Doreen |last3=Ryan |first3=Siobhan Mary |last4=Jorm |first4=Anthony Francis }}</ref><ref name=pmid24359862>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.jad.2013.11.017 |pmid=24359862 |title=Parenting strategies for reducing the risk of adolescent depression and anxiety disorders: A Delphi consensus study |journal=Journal of Affective Disorders |volume=156 |pages=67–75 |year=2014 |last1=Yap |first1=Marie B.H |last2=Pilkington |first2=Pamela D |last3=Ryan |first3=Siobhan M |last4=Kelly |first4=Claire M |last5=Jorm |first5=Anthony F }}</ref><ref>https://www.nationalelfservice.net/mental-health/anxiety/systematic-review-identifies-key-parenting-factors-associated-with-adolescent-depression-and-anxiety/{{full|date=June 2018}}</ref><ref>https://developingchild.harvard.edu/</ref> and evidence suggests that helping parents to be more effective with their children can address mental health needs.<ref name=pmid19719024>{{cite journal |doi=10.1353/foc.0.0031 |pmid=19719024 |jstor=27795049 |title=Preventing Child Abuse and Neglect with Parent Training: Evidence and Opportunities |journal=The Future of Children |volume=19 |issue=2 |pages=95–118 |year=2009 |last1=Richard p. Barth }}</ref><ref name=pmid22079931>{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/heapro/dar056 |pmid=22079931 |title=Parenting for mental health: What does the evidence say we need to do? Report of Workpackage 2 of the Data ''Prev'' project |journal=Health Promotion International |volume=26 |pages=i10–28 |year=2011 |last1=Stewart-Brown |first1=S. L |last2=Schrader-Mcmillan |first2=A }}</ref><ref>https://www.nationalelfservice.net/populations-and-settings/parenting/parent-training-works-for-child-and-adolescent-mental-health/</ref>
Assessing parenting capability has been raised in child protection and other contexts.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.community.nsw.gov.au/docswr/_assets/main/documents/researchnotes_parenting_keyissues.pdf |date=May 2006 |title=Effective parenting capacity assessment: Key issues |publisher=Centre for Parenting & Research |isbn=0-7310-4387-1 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130117044552/http://www.community.nsw.gov.au/docswr/_assets/main/documents/researchnotes_parenting_keyissues.pdf |archivedate=2013-01-17 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.childwelfare.gov/systemwide/assessment/family_assess/parentalneeds/skills.cfm |title=Assessing Parenting Skills and Competencies |publisher=Childwelfare.gov |date=|accessdate=2013-04-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.community.nsw.gov.au/docswr/_assets/main/documents/research_parenting_capacity.pdf |first=Angela |last=White |date=December 2005 |title=Assessment of parenting capacity Literature review |publisher=Centre for Parenting & Research |isbn=978-0-7310-4385-9 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121002175856/http://www.community.nsw.gov.au/docswr/_assets/main/documents/research_parenting_capacity.pdf |archivedate=2012-10-02 |df= }}{{page needed|date=May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.practicecentre.cyf.govt.nz/policy/caring-for-children-and-young-people/key-information/assessing-parenting-capacity.html |title=Assessing parenting capacity |publisher=Practice Centre |date= |accessdate=2013-04-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130504184811/http://practicecentre.cyf.govt.nz/policy/caring-for-children-and-young-people/key-information/assessing-parenting-capacity.html |archivedate=2013-05-04 |df= }}</ref> Delaying of potential [[Teenage pregnancy#Prevention|very young pregnancies]] could lead to better mental health causal risk factors such as improved parenting skills and more stable homes,<ref name=pmid7258440>{{cite journal |doi=10.2105/AJPH.71.8.796 |pmid=7258440 |pmc=1620003 |title=The biological advantages and social disadvantages of teenage pregnancy |journal=American Journal of Public Health |volume=71 |issue=8 |pages=796 |year=1981 |last1=Morris |first1=N M }}</ref> and various approaches have been used to encourage such behaviour change.<ref name="health.state.mn.us">{{cite web|url=http://www.health.state.mn.us/divs/fh/mch/fhv/strategies/tppinterventions.html |title=Adolescent Pregnancy Prevention Interventions – Family Home Visiting |publisher=Health.state.mn.us |date= |accessdate=2013-04-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130427001533/http://www.health.state.mn.us/divs/fh/mch/fhv/strategies/tppinterventions.html |archivedate=2013-04-27 |df= }}</ref><ref name=pmid19910400>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/bmj.b4254 |pmid=19910400 |pmc=2776931 |title=Teenage pregnancy and social disadvantage: Systematic review integrating controlled trials and qualitative studies |journal=BMJ |volume=339 |pages=b4254 |year=2009 |last1=Harden |first1=A |last2=Brunton |first2=G |last3=Fletcher |first3=A |last4=Oakley |first4=A }}</ref> Some countries run [[conditional cash transfer]] welfare programs where payment is conditional on behaviour of the recipients. [[Compulsory sterilization|Compulsory contraception]] has been used to prevent future mental illness.<ref>{{cite book |first=Philip |last=Reilly |title=The surgical solution: a history of involuntary sterilization in the United States |location=Baltimore |publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press |year=1991 |isbn=978-0-8018-4096-8}}{{page needed|date=May 2013}}</ref>
===Pre-emptive [[cognitive behavioural therapy|CBT]]=== Use of [[cognitive behavioral therapy|cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT)]] with people at risk has significantly reduced the number of episodes of generalized anxiety disorder and other anxiety symptoms, and also given significant improvements in explanatory style, hopelessness, and dysfunctional attitudes.<ref name="Bienvenu Ginsburg 2007">{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/09540260701797837 |title=Prevention of anxiety disorders |year=2007 |last1=Bienvenu |first1=O. Joseph |last2=Ginsburg |first2=Golda S. |journal=[[International Review of Psychiatry]] |volume=19 |issue=6 |pages=647–54 |pmid=18092242}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/1522-3736.2.1.28a |title=The prevention of depression and anxiety |year=1999 |last1=Seligman |first1=Martin E. P. |last2=Schulman |first2=Peter |last3=Derubeis |first3=Robert J. |last4=Hollon |first4=Steven D. |journal=Prevention & Treatment |volume=2 |issue=1}}</ref> In 2014 the UK [[National Institute for Health and Care Excellence|National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE)]] recommended preventive CBT for people at risk of psychosis.<ref name="thementalelf.net"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pathways.nice.org.uk/pathways/psychosis-and-schizophrenia#path=view%3A/pathways/psychosis-and-schizophrenia/prevention-in-adults-at-risk-of-developing-psychosis.xml&content=view-node%3Anodes-interventions-to-prevent-psychosis|title=Psychosis and schizophrenia|work=nice.org.uk}}</ref> As of 2018, some health providers now advocate pre-emptive use of CBT to prevent worsening of mental illnesses.<ref>http://www.hpft.nhs.uk/services/community-services/wellbeing-service/our-treatments/cognitive-behavioural-therapy-cbt/</ref>
===Mental silence [[meditation]]=== [[Sahaja yoga|Sahaja]] [[meditation|meditators]] scored above control groups for emotional well-being and mental health measures on [[SF-36]] ratings, leading to proposed use for mental illness prevention, although this result could be due to meditators having other characteristics leading to good mental health, such as higher general self care.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1155/2012/350674 |pmid=22611427 |pmc=3352577 |title=Quality of Life and Functional Health Status of Long-Term Meditators |journal=Evidence-Based Complementary and Alternative Medicine |volume=2012 |pages=350674 |year=2012 |last1=Manocha |first1=Ramesh |last2=Black |first2=Deborah |last3=Wilson |first3=Leigh }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1601-5215.2010.00519.x |title=Meditation, mindfulness and mind-emptiness |journal=Acta Neuropsychiatrica |volume=23 |issue=1 |pages=46–7 |year=2014 |last1=Manocha |first1=Ramesh }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Morgan |first1=Adam |title=Sahaja Yoga: an ancient path to modern mental health? |year=1999 |type=PhD Thesis |hdl=10026.1/1969 }}{{pn|date=June 2018}}</ref>
===Mindfulness===
An 8 week [[mindfulness]] course given to students was found to reduce the number subsequently needing treatment for [[mental illness]] by 60%, although the study was not of large size and commented that the effect could be due to 'non-specific effects', as the control group had received no attention at all, rather than an alternative intervention.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S2468-2667(17)30231-1 |pmid=29422189 |pmc=5813792 |title=A mindfulness-based intervention to increase resilience to stress in university students (the Mindful Student Study): A pragmatic randomised controlled trial |journal=The Lancet Public Health |volume=3 |issue=2 |pages=e72–e81 |year=2018 |last1=Galante |first1=Julieta |last2=Dufour |first2=Géraldine |last3=Vainre |first3=Maris |last4=Wagner |first4=Adam P |last5=Stochl |first5=Jan |last6=Benton |first6=Alice |last7=Lathia |first7=Neal |last8=Howarth |first8=Emma |last9=Jones |first9=Peter B }}</ref>
===Internet- and mobile-based interventions=== A review found that a number of studies have shown that internet- and mobile-based interventions can be effective in preventing mental disorders.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.3389/fpsyt.2017.00116 |pmid=28848454 |pmc=5554359 |title=Prevention of Mental Health Disorders Using Internet- and Mobile-Based Interventions: A Narrative Review and Recommendations for Future Research |journal=Frontiers in Psychiatry |volume=8 |pages=116 |year=2017 |last1=Ebert |first1=David Daniel |last2=Cuijpers |first2=Pim |last3=Muñoz |first3=Ricardo F |last4=Baumeister |first4=Harald }}</ref>
==Specific diseases== ===Depression=== {{See also|Major depressive disorder#Prevention|Dysthymia#Prevention}} For [[depressive disorders]], when people participated in interventions, some studies show the number of new cases is reduced by 22% to 38%.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1176/appi.ajp.2008.07091422 |title=Preventing the Onset of Depressive Disorders: A Meta-Analytic Review of Psychological Interventions |year=2008 |last1=Cuijpers |first1=Pim |journal=American Journal of Psychiatry |volume=165 |issue=10 |pages=1272–80 |pmid=18765483 |last2=Van Straten |first2=A |last3=Smit |first3=F |last4=Mihalopoulos |first4=C |last5=Beekman |first5=A}}</ref><ref name="Muñoz et al 2012">{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/a0027666 |title=Major depression can be prevented |year=2012 |last1=Muñoz |first1=Ricardo F. |last2=Beardslee |first2=William R. |last3=Leykin |first3=Yan |journal=American Psychologist |volume=67 |issue=4 |pages=285–95 |pmid=22583342|pmc=4533896}}</ref> These interventions included CBT.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.cpr.2009.04.005 |title=Psychoeducational treatment and prevention of depression: The "coping with depression" course thirty years later |year=2009 |last1=Cuijpers |first1=Pim |last2=Muñoz |first2=Ricardo F. |last3=Clarke |first3=Gregory N. |last4=Lewinsohn |first4=Peter M. |journal=Clinical Psychology Review |volume=29 |issue=5 |pages=449–58 |pmid=19450912}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.2196/jmir.8241 |pmid=29097357 |pmc=5691241 |title=Preventing Depression in Final Year Secondary Students: School-Based Randomized Controlled Trial |journal=Journal of Medical Internet Research |volume=19 |issue=11 |pages=e369 |year=2017 |last1=Perry |first1=Yael |last2=Werner-Seidler |first2=Aliza |last3=Calear |first3=Alison |last4=MacKinnon |first4=Andrew |last5=King |first5=Catherine |last6=Scott |first6=Jan |last7=Merry |first7=Sally |last8=Fleming |first8=Theresa |last9=Stasiak |first9=Karolina |last10=Christensen |first10=Helen |last11=Batterham |first11=Philip J }}</ref> Such interventions also save costs.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1001/archpsyc.63.3.290 |title=Opportunities for Cost-effective Prevention of Late-Life Depression: An Epidemiological Approach |year=2006 |last1=Smit |first1=Filip |journal=Archives of General Psychiatry |volume=63 |issue=3 |pages=290–6 |pmid=16520434 |last2=Ederveen |first2=A |last3=Cuijpers |first3=P |last4=Deeg |first4=D |last5=Beekman |first5=A}}</ref> Depression prevention continues to be called for.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S2215-0366(15)00555-6 |pmid=26827251 |title=Prevention of depression worldwide: A wake-up call |journal=The Lancet Psychiatry |volume=3 |issue=4 |pages=306–7 |year=2016 |last1=Muñoz |first1=Ricardo F |last2=Bunge |first2=Eduardo L }}</ref>
===Anxiety=== {{See also|Anxiety disorder#Prevention}} For [[anxiety disorder]]s, * use of [[cognitive behavioral therapy]] (CBT) with people at risk has significantly reduced the number of episodes of generalized anxiety disorder and other anxiety symptoms, and also given significant improvements in explanatory style, hopelessness, and dysfunctional attitudes.<ref name="Bienvenu Ginsburg 2007">{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/09540260701797837 |title=Prevention of anxiety disorders |year=2007 |last1=Bienvenu |first1=O. Joseph |last2=Ginsburg |first2=Golda S. |journal=[[International Review of Psychiatry]] |volume=19 |issue=6 |pages=647–54 |pmid=18092242}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/1522-3736.2.1.28a |title=The prevention of depression and anxiety |year=1999 |last1=Seligman |first1=Martin E. P. |last2=Schulman |first2=Peter |last3=Derubeis |first3=Robert J. |last4=Hollon |first4=Steven D. |journal=Prevention & Treatment |volume=2 |issue=1}}</ref> Other interventions (parental inhibition reduction, behaviourism, parental modelling, problem-solving and communication skills) have also produced significant benefits.<ref name="Bienvenu Ginsburg 2007"/> People with subthreshold panic disorder were found to benefit from use of CBT.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0005-7894(01)80017-4 |title=Prevention of panic disorder |year=2001 |last1=Gardenswartz |first1=Cara Ann |last2=Craske |first2=Michelle G. |journal=Behavior Therapy |volume=32 |issue=4 |pages=725–37}}</ref> * for older people, a stepped-care intervention (watchful waiting, [[Cognitive behavioral therapy|CBT]] and medication if appropriate) achieved a 50% lower incidence rate of depression and anxiety disorders in a patient group aged 75 or older.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1001/archgenpsychiatry.2008.555 |title=Stepped-Care Prevention of Anxiety and Depression in Late Life: A Randomized Controlled Trial |year=2009 |last1=Van't Veer-Tazelaar |first1=Petronella J. |journal=Archives of General Psychiatry |volume=66 |issue=3 |pages=297–304 |pmid=19255379 |last2=Van Marwijk |first2=HW |last3=Van Oppen |first3=P |last4=Van Hout |first4=HP |last5=Van Der Horst |first5=HE |last6=Cuijpers |first6=P |last7=Smit |first7=F |last8=Beekman |first8=AT|hdl=1871/16425 }}</ref>{{Primary source inline|date=October 2015}} * for younger people, it has been found that teaching CBT in schools reduced anxiety in children,<ref>{{cite web|title=CBT lessons in school reduce anxiety in children|url= http://www.bath.ac.uk/research/news/2014/07/16/cbt-primary-schools/|work=University of Bath|accessdate=18 July 2014|date=16 July 2014}}</ref> and a review found that most universal, selective and indicated prevention programs are effective in reducing symptoms of anxiety in children and adolescents.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.cpr.2009.01.002 |pmid=19232805 |title=Efficacy and effectiveness of school-based prevention and early intervention programs for anxiety |journal=Clinical Psychology Review |volume=29 |issue=3 |pages=208–15 |year=2009 |last1=Neil |first1=Alison L |last2=Christensen |first2=Helen }}</ref> * for university students [[mindfulness]] has been shown to reduce subsequent anxiety.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S2468-2667(17)30231-1 |pmid=29422189 |title=A mindfulness-based intervention to increase resilience to stress in university students (the Mindful Student Study): A pragmatic randomised controlled trial |journal=The Lancet Public Health |volume=3 |issue=2 |pages=e72–e81 |year=2018 |last1=Galante |first1=Julieta |last2=Dufour |first2=Géraldine |last3=Vainre |first3=Maris |last4=Wagner |first4=Adam P |last5=Stochl |first5=Jan |last6=Benton |first6=Alice |last7=Lathia |first7=Neal |last8=Howarth |first8=Emma |last9=Jones |first9=Peter B }}</ref>
===Psychosis=== {{See also|Psychosis#Prevention|Prevention of schizophrenia}} In those at high risk there is tentative evidence that [[psychosis]] incidence may be reduced with the use of CBT or other types of therapy.<ref name=pmid23335473>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/bmj.f185 |pmid=23335473 |pmc=3548617 |title=Early interventions to prevent psychosis: Systematic review and meta-analysis |journal=BMJ |volume=346 |pages=f185 |year=2013 |last1=Stafford |first1=M. R |last2=Jackson |first2=H |last3=Mayo-Wilson |first3=E |last4=Morrison |first4=A. P |last5=Kendall |first5=T }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/schbul/sbw084 |pmid=27306315 |pmc=5605258 |title=Four-Year Cost-effectiveness of Cognitive Behavior Therapy for Preventing First-episode Psychosis: The Dutch Early Detection Intervention Evaluation (EDIE-NL) Trial |journal=Schizophrenia Bulletin |volume=43 |issue=2 |pages=365–374 |year=2016 |last1=Ising |first1=Helga K |last2=Lokkerbol |first2=Joran |last3=Rietdijk |first3=Judith |last4=Dragt |first4=Sara |last5=Klaassen |first5=Rianne M. C |last6=Kraan |first6=Tamar |last7=Boonstra |first7=Nynke |last8=Nieman |first8=Dorien H |last9=Van Den Berg |first9=David P. G |last10=Linszen |first10=Don H |last11=Wunderink |first11=Lex |last12=Veling |first12=Wim |last13=Smit |first13=Filip |last14=Van Der Gaag |first14=Mark }}</ref> In 2014 the UK [[National Institute for Health and Care Excellence|National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE)]] recommended preventive CBT for people at risk of psychosis.<ref name="thementalelf.net"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pathways.nice.org.uk/pathways/psychosis-and-schizophrenia#path=view%3A/pathways/psychosis-and-schizophrenia/prevention-in-adults-at-risk-of-developing-psychosis.xml&content=view-node%3Anodes-interventions-to-prevent-psychosis|title=Psychosis and schizophrenia|work=nice.org.uk}}</ref>
There is also tentative evidence that treatment may help those with early symptoms.<ref name=pmid21678345>{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/14651858.CD004718.pub3 |pmid=21678345 |pmc=4163966 |title=Early intervention for psychosis |journal=Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews |issue=6 |pages=CD004718 |year=2011 |last1=Marshall |first1=Max |last2=Rathbone |first2=John }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1017/S0033291713000354 |title=Cognitive behavioural therapy for psychosis prevention: A systematic review and meta-analysis |year=2013 |last1=Hutton |first1=P. |last2=Taylor |first2=P. J. |journal=Psychological Medicine |pages=1–20 |pmid=23521867 |volume=44|issue=3 }}</ref> [[Antipsychotic medication]]s are not recommended for preventing psychosis.<ref name="thementalelf.net">{{cite web|url=http://www.thementalelf.net/treatment-and-prevention/medicines/antipsychotics/psychosis-and-schizophrenia-in-adults-updated-nice-guidance-for-2014/|title=Psychosis and schizophrenia in adults: updated NICE guidance for 2014|work=National Elf Service}}</ref>
For [[schizophrenia]], one study of preventative CBT showed a positive effect<ref name=pmid23335473/> and another showed neutral effect.<ref name=pmid23218022>{{cite journal |doi=10.4088/JCP.12m07785 |pmid=23218022 |title=Randomized Controlled Trial of Interventions for Young People at Ultra-High Risk of Psychosis |journal=The Journal of Clinical Psychiatry |volume=74 |issue=4 |pages=349–56 |year=2013 |last1=McGorry |first1=Patrick D |last2=Nelson |first2=Barnaby |last3=Phillips |first3=Lisa J |last4=Yuen |first4=Hok Pan |last5=Francey |first5=Shona M |last6=Thampi |first6=Annette |last7=Berger |first7=Gregor E |last8=Amminger |first8=G. Paul |last9=Simmons |first9=Magenta B |last10=Kelly |first10=Daniel |last11=Thompson |first11=Andrew D |last12=Yung |first12=Alison R }}</ref>
==Targeted vs universal== There has been an historical trend among public health professionals to consider targeted programmes. However identification of high risk groups can increase stigma, in turn meaning that the targeted people do not engage. Thus policy recommends universal programs, with resources within such programs weighted towards high risk groups.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fph.org.uk/examples_of_interventions |title=UK Faculty of Public Health :: Examples of interventions |publisher=Fph.org.uk |date=2013-01-07 |accessdate=2014-04-15}}</ref>
Universal prevention (aimed at a population that has no increased risk for developing a mental disorder, such as school programs or mass media campaigns) need very high numbers of people to show effect (sometimes known as the "power" problem). Approaches to overcome this are (1) focus on high-incidence groups (e.g. by targeting groups with high risk factors), (2) use multiple interventions to achieve greater, and thus more statistically valid, effects, (3) use cumulative meta-analyses of many trials, and (4) run very large trials.<ref name="Muñoz et al 2010">{{cite journal |doi=10.1146/annurev-clinpsy-033109-132040 |title=Prevention of Major Depression |year=2010 |last1=Muñoz |first1=Ricardo F. |last2=Cuijpers |first2=Pim |last3=Smit |first3=Filip |last4=Barrera |first4=Alinne Z. |last5=Leykin |first5=Yan |journal=Annual Review of Clinical Psychology |volume=6 |pages=181–212 |pmid=20192789}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1176/appi.ajp.160.8.1385 |title=Examining the Effects of Prevention Programs on the Incidence of New Cases of Mental Disorders: The Lack of Statistical Power |year=2003 |last1=Cuijpers |first1=P. |journal=American Journal of Psychiatry |volume=160 |issue=8 |pages=1385–91 |pmid=12900296}}</ref>
==History==
===History of mental illness prevention strategies===
* In 2018 the [[University of Birmingham]] Mental Health Policy Commission focused on prevention, including the challenges of funding given the shortness of political cycles versus the longer paybacks of prevention.<ref>https://www.birmingham.ac.uk//research/impact/policy-commissions/mental-health</ref> * In 2018 11 European researchers published a review of mental illness prevention stating that "''Increasing evidence suggests that preventive interventions in psychiatry that are feasible, safe, and cost-effective could translate into a broader focus on prevention in our field.''" and that "''Gaps between knowledge, policy, and practice need to be bridged.''"<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S2215-0366(18)30057-9 |pmid=29773478 |title=Preventive strategies for mental health |journal=The Lancet Psychiatry |year=2018 |last1=Arango |first1=Celso |last2=Díaz-Caneja |first2=Covadonga M |last3=McGorry |first3=Patrick D |last4=Rapoport |first4=Judith |last5=Sommer |first5=Iris E |last6=Vorstman |first6=Jacob A |last7=McDaid |first7=David |last8=Marín |first8=Oscar |last9=Serrano-Drozdowskyj |first9=Elena |last10=Freedman |first10=Robert |last11=Carpenter |first11=William }}</ref> * In 2018 [[Massachusetts]] announced a mental health strategy including many prevention elements. The executive summary began "''Behavioral health promotion and upstream prevention works.''"<ref>https://www.promoteprevent.com/{{full|date=June 2018}}</ref> * In 2017 the Australian Government funded a new Centre for Research Excellence in Prevention of Anxiety and Depression.<ref>{{cite web |last=Cross |first=Brooke |date=10 May 2017 |title=World-class mental health research centre announced in Budget 2017 |website=Hunter Institute of Mental Health |url=http://www.himh.org.au/home/news-and-media/news/2017/world-class-mental-health-research-centre-announced-in-budget-2017 }}</ref> * The US [[Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration]] (SAMHSA) advocates a 5-step prevention framework.<ref>{{cite web |date=20 January 2017 |title=SAMHSA's Efforts Related to Prevention and Early Intervention |website=[[Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration]] |publisher=U.S. Department of Health and Human Services |url=http://www.samhsa.gov/prevention/samhsas-efforts }}</ref> * In 2016: ** the UK NHS Mental Health Taskforce included 'preventing mental health' in its 3 Priorities, focusing on children and young ages, and the importance of employment.<ref>https://www.england.nhs.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Mental-Health-Taskforce-FYFV-final.pdf{{full|date=June 2018}}</ref> **the UK NGO [[Mental Health Foundation]] published a review of prevention approaches.<ref>{{cite web |title=Mental health and prevention: taking local action for better mental health |website=Mental Health Foundation |url=https://www.mentalhealth.org.uk/publications/mental-health-and-prevention-taking-local-action-better-mental-health }}</ref> **the UK NGO [[Mind (charity)|Mind]] produced public mental health recommendations for more prevention.<ref name="mind.org.uk">https://www.mind.org.uk/media/2976113/mind_public-mental-health-guide_web-version.pdf{{full|date=June 2018}}</ref> * In 2015: ** the Hunter Institute of mental health in Australia published its "Prevention First" strategic framework for prevention.<ref>{{cite web |date=19 March 2015 |title=New Prevention Framework to support mental health of all Australians |website=Hunter Institute of Mental Health |url=http://himh.clients.squiz.net/home/news-and-media/news/2015/new-prevention-framework-to-support }}</ref> ** the UK NGO [[Mental Health Foundation]] published a review of prevention research, paving the way for prevention strategies.<ref>{{cite report|url=http://www.mentalhealth.org.uk/content/assets/PDF/publications/prevention-review.pdf |format=PDF |last1=Woodhouse |first1=Amy |last2=Shields |first2=Jessica |last3=Goldie |first3=Isabella |last4=Breedvelt |first4=Josefien |last5=Elliott |first5=Iris |last6=McLean |first6=Joanne |date=November 2015 |title=Prevention Review: Landscape Paper |type=Research Paper |publisher=Mental Health convincing, and the time is now ripe to move from knowledge to action"''.<ref name=pmid25655149>{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/wps.20178 |pmid=25655149 |pmc=4329888 |title=Public mental health: The time |location=Canberra ACT, Australia |title=Fourth National Mental Health Plan: An agenda for collaborative government action in mental health 2009–2014 |chapter-url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/Content/SEN/Committee/391/soci/rep/rep02may06part6-e.htm |title=Out of the Shadows at Last: Transforming Mental Health, Mental Illness and Addiction Services in Canada |url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/Content/SEN/Committee/391/soci/rep/rep02may06-e.htm |publisher=Parliament of Canada}}</ref>
===History of mental illness prevention programmes===
Historically prevention has been a very small part of the spend of mental health systems. For instance the 2009 UK Department of Health analysis of prevention expenditure did not include any apparent spend on mental health.<ref>{{cite report |last1=Butterfield |first1=Rebecca |last2=Henderson |first2=John |last3=Scott |first3=Robert |date=May 2009 |title=Public Health and Prevention Expenditure in England |type=Health England Report |volume=4 |publisher=Department of Health |location=London |url=http://www.healthengland.org/publications/HealthEnglandReportNo4.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090913095407/http://www.healthengland.org/publications/HealthEnglandReportNo4.pdf |archive-date=13 September 2009}}</ref> The situation is the same in research.<ref name="schizophreniacommission.org.uk">{{cite web|url=http://www.schizophreniacommission.org.uk/the-report/ |title=The Report |publisher=The Schizophrenia Commission |date=2012-11-13 |accessdate=2013-04-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130405104051/http://www.schizophreniacommission.org.uk/the-report/ |archivedate=2013-04-05 |df= }}</ref>
However more recently some prevention programmes have been proposed or implemented. Prevention programmes can include public health policies to raise general health, creating supportive environments, strengthening communities, developing personal skills, and reorienting services.<ref name="mind.org.uk"/>
* In 2017 the UK [[Public Health England|PHE]] and [[London School of Economics|LSE]] produced research showing short payback periods for a number of prevention interventions.<ref>https://www.gov.uk/government/news/phe-highlights-8-ways-for-local-areas-to-prevent-mental-ill-health{{full|date=June 2018}}</ref> * In 2017 the Scotland Mental Health Strategy included prevention, including a focus on improving parenting skills.<ref>http://www.gov.scot/Publications/2017/03/1750{{full|date=June 2018}}</ref> * In 2016, the UK [[Education Policy Institute]] advocated prevention through increased mental health literacy, better parenting and improving children's resilience and digital world skills.<ref>{{cite web|title=Children and Young People's Mental Health|url=http://epi.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/time-to-deliver-web.pdf|accessdate=6 December 2016}}</ref> * In 2013 the UK NGO [[Mental Health Foundation]] and partners began to use [[Video interaction guidance|Video Interaction Guidance (VIG)]] in an early years intervention to reduce later life mental illness.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mentalhealth.org.uk/our-work/research/sutton-early-intervention-project/ |title=Babies in Mind – Early Intervention in Sutton |publisher=Mentalhealth.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-04-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://secure.thebiggive.org.uk/projects/view/20729/babies-in-mind |title=Babies In Mind, a project by Home-Start Sutton | The Big Give |publisher=Secure.thebiggive.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-04-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140321110845/https://secure.thebiggive.org.uk/projects/view/20729/babies-in-mind |archivedate=2014-03-21 |df= }}</ref> * In 2013 in Australia the [[National Health and Medical Research Council]] supported a set of parenting strategies to prevent teenagers becoming anxious or depressed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parentingstrategies.net/depression/index.php |title=Preventing Depression & Anxiety – Home Page |publisher=Parenting Strategies |date= |accessdate=2014-04-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beyondblue.org.au/about-us/news/news/2013/08/30/a-new-guide-to-help-navigate-the-terrible-teens |title=A new guide to help navigate the terrible teens |publisher=Beyondblue.org.au |date= |accessdate=2014-04-15}}</ref> * In 2012 the UK Schizophrenia Commission recommended ''"a preventative strategy for psychosis including promoting protective factors for mental wellbeing and reducing risks such as cannabis use in early adolescence."''<ref name="schizophreniacommission.org.uk"/> * In 2010 the [[European Union]] DataPrev database was launched. It states ''"A healthy start is crucial for mental health and wellbeing throughout life, with parenting being the single most important factor,"'' and recommends a range of interventions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dataprevproject.net/Parenting_and_Early_Years/ |title=DataPrev |publisher=Dataprevproject.net |date= |accessdate=2014-04-15}}</ref> * In 2009 the US National Academies publication on preventing mental, emotional, and behavioral disorders among young people focused on recent research and program experience and stated that ''"A number of promotion and prevention programs are now available that should be considered for broad implementation."''<ref>{{cite book |editor1-first=Mary Ellen |editor1-last=O'Connell |editor2-first=Thomas |editor2-last=Boat |editor3-first=Kenneth E. |editor3-last=Warner |url=http://www.nap.edu/catalog.php?record_id=12480 |publisher=National Academies Press |title=Prevention of Mental Disorders, Substance Abuse, and Problem Behaviors: A Developmental Perspective |year=2009 |isbn=978-0-309-12674-8}}{{page needed|date=May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |pmid=16757984 |year=2006 |last1=Saxena |first1=S |last2=Jané-Llopis |first2=E |last3=Hosman |first3=C |title=Prevention of mental and behavioural disorders: Implications for policy and practice |volume=5 |issue=1 |pages=5–14 |pmc=1472261 |journal=World Psychiatry}}</ref> A 2011 review of this by the authors said ''"A scientific base of evidence shows that we can prevent many mental, emotional, and behavioral disorders before they begin"'' and made recommendations including ** supporting the mental health and parenting skills of parents, ** encouraging the developmental competencies of children and ** using preventive strategies particularly for children at risk (such as children of parents with mental illness, or with family stresses such as divorce or job loss).<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1176/ps.62.3.pss6203_0247 |title=Prevention of Mental Disorders, Substance Abuse, and Problem Behaviors: A Developmental Perspective |year=2011 |last1=Beardslee |first1=W. R. |last2=Chien |first2=P. L. |last3=Bell |first3=C. C. |journal=Psychiatric Services |volume=62 |issue=3 |pages=247–54 |pmid=21363895}}</ref>
In India the 1982 National Mental health Programme included prevention,<ref>{{cite web |title=National Mental Health Programme |url=http://nihfw.nic.in/ndc-nihfw/html/Programmes/NationalMentalHealth.htm |website=National Institute of Health & Family Welfare |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140810015119/http://nihfw.nic.in/ndc-nihfw/html/Programmes/NationalMentalHealth.htm |archive-date=10 August 2014}}</ref> but implementation has been slow, particularly of prevention elements.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/aurangabad/Jalna-Zilla-Parishad-takes-up-fight-against-mental-illness/articleshow/36367342.cms|title=Jalna Zilla Parishad takes up fight against mental illness|work=The Times of India}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title=National Mental Health Programme (NMHP) |date=23 July 2012 |url=http://mohfw.nic.in/WriteReadData/l892s/9903463892NMHP%20detail.pdf |format=PDF |publisher=Ministry of Health & Family Welfare |location=New Delhi, India |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140727132519/http://mohfw.nic.in/WriteReadData/l892s/9903463892NMHP%20detail.pdf |archivedate=27 July 2014 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slideshare.net/satyakammohapatra39/national-mental-health-programme-nmhp|title=National mental health programme (nmhp)|author=Satyakam Mohapatra|work=slideshare.net}}</ref>
It is already known that home visiting programs for pregnant women and parents of young children can produce replicable effects on children's general health and development in a variety of community settings.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1469-7610.2006.01702.x |title=Programs for parents of infants and toddlers: Recent evidence from randomized trials |year=2007 |last1=Olds |first1=David L. |last2=Sadler |first2=Lois |last3=Kitzman |first3=Harriet |journal=Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry |volume=48 |issue=3–4 |pages=355–91 |pmid=17355402}}</ref> Similarly positive benefits from social and emotional education are well proven.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1467-8624.2010.01564.x |title=The Impact of Enhancing Students' Social and Emotional Learning: A Meta-Analysis of School-Based Universal Interventions |year=2011 |last1=Durlak |first1=Joseph A. |last2=Weissberg |first2=Roger P. |last3=Dymnicki |first3=Allison B. |last4=Taylor |first4=Rebecca D. |last5=Schellinger |first5=Kriston B. |journal=Child Development |volume=82 |pages=405–32 |pmid=21291449 |issue=1}}</ref> Research has shown that risk assessment and behavioral interventions in pediatric clinics reduced abuse and neglect outcomes for young children.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1542/peds.2008-1376 |title=Pediatric Primary Care to Help Prevent Child Maltreatment: The Safe Environment for Every Kid (SEEK) Model |year=2009 |last1=Dubowitz |first1=H. |last2=Feigelman |first2=S. |last3=Lane |first3=W. |last4=Kim |first4=J. |journal=Pediatrics |volume=123 |issue=3 |pages=858–64 |pmid=19255014}}</ref> Early childhood home visitation also reduced abuse and neglect, but results were inconsistent.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.7326/0003-4819-158-3-201302050-00590 |title=Behavioral Interventions and Counseling to Prevent Child Abuse and Neglect: A Systematic Review to Update the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force Recommendation |year=2013 |last1=Selph |first1=Shelley S. |journal=Annals of Internal Medicine |volume=158 |issue=3 |pages=179–90 |pmid=23338775 |last2=Bougatsos |first2=C |last3=Blazina |first3=I |last4=Nelson |first4=HD}}</ref>
==Issues in implementation== Prevention programs can face issues in (i) ownership, because health systems are typically targeted at current suffering, and (ii) funding, because program benefits come on longer timescales than the normal political and management cycle.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1186/1743-8462-6-25 |title=Funding illness prevention and health promotion in Australia: A way forward |year=2009 |last1=Harris |first1=Anthony |last2=Mortimer |first2=Duncan |journal=Australia and New Zealand Health Policy |volume=6 |page=25 |pmid=19909519 |pmc=2780431 |issue=1}}</ref><ref>{{citation |author1=Executive Office of the President: Office of Management and Budget |date=13 April 2011 |title=Statement of Administration Policy: H.R. 1217 – Repeal of the Affordable Care Act's Prevention and Public Health Fund (Rep. Pitts, R-PA, and 3 cosponsors) |location=Washington, DC |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/omb/legislative/sap/112/saphr1217h_20110413.pdf |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120504061531/http://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/omb/legislative/sap/112/saphr1217h_20110413.pdf |archivedate=4 May 2012 |df= }}</ref> Assembling collaborations of interested bodies appears to be an effective model for achieving sustained commitment and funding.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mrc.ac.uk/Ourresearch/ResearchInitiatives/NPRI/index.htm |publisher=Medical Research Council |title=National Prevention Research Initiative |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311061911/http://www.mrc.ac.uk/Ourresearch/ResearchInitiatives/NPRI/index.htm |archivedate=2012-03-11 |df= }}</ref>

{{about|the United States law|the band|Pure Food and Drug Act (band)}} {{distinguish|Food and Drugs Act}} {{Infobox U.S. legislation | shorttitle= Pure Food and Drug Act | colloquialacronym= PFDA | enacted by= 59th | effective date= January 1, 1907 | public law url= https://research.archives.gov/id/5716297 | cite public law= 59-384 | cite statutes at large= {{usstat|34|768}}, Chapter 3915 | acts amended= | acts repealed= {{unbulleted list|Pure Food and Drug Act (1906)|37 U.S. Stat. 416 (1912) (Sherley Amendment)|37 U.S. Stat. 732 (1913) ([[Gould Amendment]])|41 U.S. Stat. 271 (1919) (Kenyon Amendment)|42 U.S. Stat. 1500 (1923)|44 U.S. Stat. 976-1003 (1927)|46 U.S. Stat. 1019 (1930) (McNary-Mapes Amendment)|48 U.S. Stat. 1204 (1934) ([[Title 21 of the United States Code|21 U.S.C. §§ 1-15]])}} | title amended= [[Title 21 of the United States Code|21 U.S.C.: Food and Drugs]] | sections created= | sections amended= | leghisturl= | introducedin= Senate | introducedbill= {{USBill|59|S.|88}} | introducedby= [[Weldon B. Heyburn|Weldon Heyburn]] ([[Republican Party (United States)|R]]–[[Idaho|ID]]) | introduceddate= December 14, 1905 | committees= | passedbody1= Senate | passeddate1= February 21, 1906 | passedvote1= [http://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/59-1/s8 63-4] | passedbody2= House | passeddate2= June 20, 1906 | passedvote2= [http://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/59-1/h95 143-72] | conferencedate= June 23, 1906 | passedbody3=House | passeddate3= June 23, 1906 | passedvote3= Did not agree | passedbody4= Senate | passeddate4= June 23, 1906 | passedvote4= [http://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/59-1/h97 241-17] | signedpresident= [[Theodore Roosevelt]] | signeddate= June 30, 1906 | amendments= [[Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act|Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act]] (1938)
[[Food Quality Protection Act]] (1996) | SCOTUS cases= ''[[United States v. Johnson (1911)|United States v. Johnson]]'' (1911) }} The '''[[s:Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906|Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906]]''' was the first of a series of significant [[consumer protection law]]s which was enacted by Congress in the 20th century and led to the creation of the [[Food and Drug Administration]]. Its main purpose was to ban foreign and interstate traffic in adulterated or mislabeled food and drug products, and it directed the U.S. Bureau of Chemistry to inspect products and refer offenders to prosecutors. It required that active ingredients be placed on the label of a drug’s packaging and that drugs could not fall below purity levels established by the United States Pharmacopeia or the National Formulary. ''[[The Jungle]]'' by [[Upton Sinclair]] was an inspirational piece that kept the public's attention on the important issue of unsanitary meat processing plants that later led to food inspection legislation. Sinclair quipped, "I aimed at the public's heart and by accident I hit it in the stomach," as readers demanded and got the pure food law.Arlene F. Kantor, "Upton Sinclair and the Pure Food and Drugs Act of 1906: 'I aimed at the public's heart and by accident I hit it in the stomach,'" ''American Journal of Public Health'' 66.12 (1976): 1202-1205. ==Historical significance== The '''Pure Food and Drug Act''' of 1906 was a key piece of Progressive Era legislation, signed by President Theodore Roosevelt on the same day as the [[Federal Meat Inspection Act]]. Enforcement of the Pure Food and Drug Act was assigned to the Bureau of Chemistry in the U.S. Department of Agriculture which was renamed the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in 1930. The [[Meat Inspection Act]] was assigned to what is now known as the [[Food Safety and Inspection Service]], which remains in the U.S. Department of Agriculture. The first federal law regulating foods and drugs, the 1906 Act's reach was limited to foods and drugs moving in [[Commerce Clause|interstate commerce]]. Although the law drew upon many precedents, provisions, and legal experiments pioneered in individual states, the federal law defined "misbranding" and "adulteration" for the first time and prescribed penalties for each. The law recognized the U.S. Pharmacopeia and the National Formulary as standards authorities for drugs, but made no similar provision for federal food standards.{{cite web |url=http://www.fda.gov/AboutFDA/WhatWeDo/History/Origin/ucm054819.htm |title=The 1906 Food and Drugs Act and Its Enforcement |author=Swann, Ph.D., John P |series=FDA History - Part I |publisher=U.S. Food and Drug Administration |accessdate=10 April 2013}} The law was principally a "truth in labeling" law designed to raise standards in the food and drug industries and protect the reputations and pocketbooks of honest businessmen. ==Particular drugs deemed addictive== Under the law, drug labels, for example, had to list any of 10 ingredients that were deemed "addictive" and/or "dangerous" on the product label if they were present, and could not list them if they were not present. [[Alcohol]], [[morphine]], [[opium]], and [[cannabis]] were all included on the list of these "addictive" and/or "dangerous" drugs. The law also established a federal cadre of food and drug inspectors that one Southern opponent of the legislation criticized as "a Trojan horse with a bellyful of inspectors and other employees."Young, James H. [https://books.google.com/books?id=vw8ABAAAQBAJ&pg=PA98&lpg=PA98&dq=a+Trojan+horse+with+a+bellyful+of+inspectors&source=bl&ots=OmZtAIaLIb&sig=jKvKl8taJFCuAKHsVoQs7LK8ybE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiHupzo3cPKAhXLth4KHYKgAKAQ6AEIKDAC#v=onepage&q&f=false Pure Food: Securing the Federal Food and Drugs Act of 1906.] Princeton, N.J: Princeton University Press, 1989, p. 98. Penalties under the law were modest, but an under-appreciated provision of the Act proved more powerful than monetary penalties. Goods found in violation of various areas of the law were subject to seizure and destruction at the expense of the manufacturer. That, combined with a legal requirement that all convictions be published as Notices of Judgment, proved to be important tools in the enforcement of the statute and had a deterrent effect upon would-be violators.[https://ceb.nlm.nih.gov/fdanj/ FDA Notices of Judgment Collection, 1908-1966] Deficiencies in this original statute{{For example?}}, which had become noticeable by the 1920s, led to the replacement of the 1906 statute with the [[Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act]] which was enacted in 1938 and signed by President Franklin Roosevelt. This act, along with its numerous amendments, remains the statutory basis for federal regulation of all foods, drugs, biological products, cosmetics, medical devices, tobacco, and radiation-emitting devices by the U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]]. ==History of passage== It took 27 years to the 1906 statute, during which time the public was made aware of many problems with foods and drugs in the U.S. [[Muckraker|Muckraking]] journalists, such as [[Samuel Hopkins Adams]], targeted the [[patent medicine]] industry with its high-alcoholic content patent medicines, soothing syrups for infants with opium derivatives, and "red clauses" in newspaper contracts providing that patent medicine ads (upon which most newspapers of the time were dependent) would be withdrawn if the paper expressed support for food and drug regulatory legislation. The Chief Chemist of the Bureau of Chemistry, Dr. [[Harvey Washington Wiley]], captured the country's attention with his hygienic table studies, which began with a modest Congressional appropriation in 1902. The goal of the table trial was to study the human effects of common preservatives used in foods during a period of rapid changes in the food supply brought about by the need to feed cities and support an industrializing nation increasingly dependent on immigrant labor. Wiley recruited young men to eat all their meals at a common table as he added increased "doses" of preservatives including borax, benzoate, formaldehyde, sulfites, and salicylates. The table trials captured the nation's fancy and were soon dubbed "The Poison Squad" by newspapers covering the story. The men soon adopted the motto "Only the Brave dare eat the fare" and at times the publicity given to the trials became a burden. Though many results of the trial came to be in dispute, there was no doubt that formaldehyde was dangerous and it disappeared quickly as a preservative. Wiley himself felt that he had found adverse effects from large doses of each of the preservatives and the public seemed to agree with Wiley. In many cases, most particularly with ketchup and other condiments, the use of preservatives was often used to disguise insanitary production practices. Although the law itself did not proscribe the use of some of these preservatives, consumers increasingly turned away from many products with known preservatives. The 1906 statute regulated food and drugs moving in interstate commerce and forbade the manufacture, sale, or transportation of poisonous patent medicines.{{cite journal |last=Ayers |first=Edward A. |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=August 1907 |title=What The Food Law Saves Us From: Adulterations, Substitutions, Chemical Dyes, and Other Evils |journal=[[World's Work|The World's Work: A History of Our Time]] |volume=XIV |issue= |pages=9316–9322 |id= |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=sojNAAAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PA9316|accessdate=2009-07-10 |quote= }} The Act arose due to public education and exposés from public interest guardians such as Upton Sinclair and Samuel Hopkins Adams, social activist [[Florence Kelley]], researcher [[Harvey W. Wiley]], and President Theodore Roosevelt. == Beginnings of the Food and Drug Administration== The 1906 Act paved the way for the eventual creation of the [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) and is generally considered to be that agency's founding date, though the agency existed before the law was passed and was not named FDA until later. "While the Food and Drug act remains a foundational law of the FDA mission, it's not the law that created the FDA. [Initially,] the [[Bureau of Chemistry]] (the precursor to the FDA) regulated food safety. In 1927, the Bureau was reorganized into the Food, Drug, and Insecticide Administration and the Bureau of Chemistry and Soils. The FDIA was renamed the FDA in 1930."{{Cite web|url=https://www.fda.gov/AboutFDA/WhatWeDo/History/Milestones/ucm128305.htm|title=Milestones in U.S. Food and Drug Law History - Significant Dates in U.S. Food and Drug Law History|website=www.fda.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-11-17}} The law itself was largely replaced by the much more comprehensive [[Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act]] of 1938. == Enforcement of labeling and future ramifications == The Pure Food and Drug Act was initially concerned with ensuring products were labeled correctly. Later efforts were made to outlaw certain products that were not safe, followed by efforts to outlaw products which were safe but not effective. For example, there was an attempt to outlaw [[Coca-Cola]] in 1909 because of its excessive caffeine content; caffeine had replaced cocaine as the active ingredient in Coca-Cola in 1903.{{cite web |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2013/01/why-we-took-cocaine-out-of-soda/272694/ |title=Why We Took Cocaine Out of Soda |author=Hamblin M.D., James |date=January 31, 2013 |series=The Atlantic's Health Editorial |publisher=The Atlantic Monthly |accessdate=April 10, 2013}} In the case ''[[United States v. Forty Barrels and Twenty Kegs of Coca-Cola]]'', the judge found that Coca-Cola had a right to use caffeine as it saw fit, although Coca-Cola eventually lost when the government appealed to the Supreme Court."[http://www.apa.org/monitor/2009/02/coca-cola.aspx Pop psychology: The man who saved Coca-Cola]", by Ludy T. Benjamin, ''Monitor on Psychology,'' February 2009, Vol 40, No. 2, p. 18 It reached a settlement with the [[United States government]] to reduce the caffeine amount. In addition to caffeine, the Pure Food and Drug Act required that drugs such as [[alcohol]], [[cocaine]], [[heroin]], [[morphine]], and [[cannabis (drug)|cannabis]], be accurately labeled with contents and dosage. Previously many drugs had been sold as [[patent medicines]] with secret ingredients or misleading labels. Cocaine, heroin, cannabis, and other such drugs continued to be legally available without prescription as long as they were labeled. It is estimated that sale of patent medicines containing [[opiates]] decreased by 33% after labeling was mandated.{{cite book | last =Musto | first =David F. | year =1999|edition=3rd | title =The American Disease: Origins of Narcotic Control | publisher =Oxford University Press | isbn = 0-19-512509-6 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=7VrQy2d8PxYC }} The Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906 is cited by [[drug policy reform]] advocates such as [[James P. Gray]] as a successful model for [[drug liberalization|re-legalization]] of currently [[prohibition (drugs)|prohibited drugs]] by requiring accurate labels, monitoring of purity and dose, and consumer education.{{cite web |title=Why Our Drug Laws Have Failed and What We Can Do About It: A Judicial Indictment of the War on Drugs |author=Gray, James P. |date=May 2, 2001 |publisher=Temple University Press |pages=288 |isbn=978-1566398602}} == References == {{Reflist}} ===Sources=== {{Refbegin|2}} * {{cite journal |last=Barkan |first=I. D.|date=January 1985 |title=Industry invites regulation: the passage of the Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906 |journal=American Journal of Public Health |volume=75 |issue=1 |pages=18–26 |doi=10.2105/AJPH.75.1.18 |pmid=3881052 |pmc=1646146}} *{{cite book |title=Connecticut Agricultural & Experiment Station Annual Reports |last=The State of Connecticut |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |year= |publisher= |location=New Haven |isbn= |page= |pages= |url= |accessdate=}} For years preceding and following passage of the Act: **[https://books.google.com/books?id=0nwSAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA1# 1896], First report of the station on adulterated food products; Byrne & Company|location=Washington, D.C.|year=1907|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ngQRAAAAYAAJ}} *[[James Harvey Young]], Pure Food: Securing the Federal Food and Drugs Act of 1906 (New Jersey: Princeton University Press, 1989). *Mitchell Okun, Fair Play in the Marketplace: The First Battle for Pure Food and Drugs (Dekalb: University of Illinois Press, 1986). *Suzanne White Junod, Chemistry and Controversy: Food Additive Regulation, unpublished dissertation, Emory University, 1994. *Andrew F. Smith, Pure Ketchup: A History of America's National Condiment (Columbia: University of South Carolina Press, 1996) *Goodwin, Pure Food, Drug, and Drink Crusaders {{refend}} == External links == * {{cite web |url=https://www.visitthecapitol.gov/exhibitions/more-perfect-union-april-2010-september-2011/general-welfare/protecting-nations-food |title=S. 88, Draft bill of the Pure Food and Drug Act |author=59th U.S. Congress |date=December 14, 1905 |work=Chapter 3915, cited 34 U.S. Stats. 768 |publisher=U.S. Capitol Visitor Center |accessdate=April 8, 2013}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.fda.gov/regulatoryinformation/legislation/ucm148690.htm |title=THE WILEY ACT |author=59th U.S. Congress |work=Public Law Number 59-384, 34 Stat. 768 |year=1906 |publisher=U.S. Food and Drug Administration |accessdate=April 8, 2013}} {{Consumer Food Safety|state=expanded}} {{Theodore Roosevelt}} [[Category:1906 in American politics]] [[Category:1906 in law]] [[Category:Food and Drug Administration]] [[Category:Food law]] [[Category:Food safety in the United States]] [[Category:History of the United States (1865–1918)]] [[Category:Presidency of Theodore Roosevelt]] [[Category:Progressive Era in the United States]] [[Category:United States federal controlled substances legislation]] [[Category:United States federal health legislation]]

[[File:QALY graph-en.svg|thumb|border|320px|Demonstration of quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) for two individuals. Individual A (who did not receive an intervention) has fewer QALYs than individual B (who received an intervention).]] The '''quality-adjusted life year''' or '''quality-adjusted life-year''' ('''QALY''') is a generic measure of [[disease burden]], including both the quality and the quantity of life lived.<ref name=NICE2013>{{cite web |url=https://www.nice.org.uk/advice/lgb10/chapter/judging-the-cost-effectiveness-of-public-health-activities |title=Judging whether public health interventions offer value for money |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= September 2013 |website= |publisher=[[National Institute for Health and Care Excellence]] |access-date=2017-05-30 |quote=}}</ref><ref name=NICEglossary>{{cite web |url=https://www.nice.org.uk/glossary?letter=q |title=Glossary |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website= |publisher=[[National Institute for Health and Care Excellence]] |access-date=2017-05-30 |quote=}}</ref> It is used in [[economic evaluation]] to assess the value for money of [[medical]] interventions.<ref name=NICE2013/> One QALY equates to one year in perfect health.<ref name=NICEglossary/> If an individual's health is below this maximum, QALYs are accrued at a rate of less than 1 per year. To be dead is associated with 0 QALYs.<ref name="Weinstein2009">{{cite journal|last1=Weinstein|first1=Milton C.|last2=Torrance|first2=George|last3=McGuire|first3=Alistair|title=QALYs: The Basics|journal=Value in Health|volume=12|year=2009|pages=S5–S9|issn=10983015|doi=10.1111/j.1524-4733.2009.00515.x}}</ref> QALYs can be used to inform personal decisions, to evaluate programs, and to set priorities for future programs.<ref name="Weinstein2009"/>
== Calculation == The QALY is a measure of the value of health outcomes. It assumes that health is a function of length of life and quality of life, and combines these values into a single index number. To determine QALYs, one multiplies the [[utility]] value associated with a given state of health by the years lived in that state. A year of life lived in perfect health is worth 1 QALY (1 year of life × 1 Utility value). A year of life lived in a state of less than perfect health is worth less than 1 QALY; for example, 1 year of life lived in a situation with utility 0.5 (e.g. bedridden, 1 year × 0.5 Utility) is assigned 0.5 QALYs. Similarly, half a year lived in perfect health is equivalent to 0.5 QALYs (0.5 years × 1 Utility). Death is assigned a value of 0 QALYs, and in some circumstances it is possible to accrue negative QALYs to reflect health states deemed "worse than dead."<ref name="Weinstein2009"/>
=== Weighting === The "weight" (utility) values between 0 and 1 are usually determined by methods such as those proposed in the [[Journal of Health Economics]]:<ref>{{Cite journal | volume = 5 | issue = 1 | pages = 1–30 | last = Torrance | first = George E. | title = Measurement of health state utilities for economic appraisal: A review | journal = Journal of Health Economics | accessdate = 2014-12-01 | date = 1986 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0167629686900202 | doi=10.1016/0167-6296(86)90020-2 | pmid = 10311607 }}</ref> * [[Time-trade-off]] (TTO): Respondents are asked to choose between remaining in a state of ill health for a period of time, or being restored to perfect health but having a shorter life expectancy. * Standard gamble (SG): Respondents are asked to choose between remaining in a state of ill health for a period of time, or choosing a medical intervention which has a chance of either restoring them to perfect health, or killing them. * [[Visual analogue scale]] (VAS): Respondents are asked to rate a state of ill health on a scale from 0 to 100, with 0 representing being dead and 100 representing perfect health. This method has the advantage of being the easiest to ask, but is the most subjective.
Another way of determining the weight associated with a particular health state is to use standard descriptive systems such as the EuroQol Group's [[EQ-5D]] questionnaire, which categorises health states according to five dimensions: mobility, self-care, usual activities (e.g. work, study, homework or leisure activities), pain/discomfort and anxiety/depression.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = EuroQol--a new facility for the measurement of health-related quality of life|journal = Health Policy (Amsterdam, Netherlands)|date = 1990-12-01|issn = 0168-8510|pmid = 10109801|pages = 199–208|volume = 16|issue = 3|last = EuroQol Group|doi=10.1016/0168-8510(90)90421-9}}</ref>
== Use == Data on medical costs are often combined with QALYs in [[cost-utility analysis]] to estimate the cost-per-QALY associated with a health care intervention. This parameter can be used to develop a [[cost-effectiveness analysis]] of any treatment. This [[incremental cost-effectiveness ratio]] (ICER) can then be used to allocate [[Health care|healthcare]] resources, often using a threshold approach.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Critical ratios and efficient allocation|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0047272773900029|journal = Journal of Public Economics|date = 1973-04-01|pages = 147–157|volume = 2|issue = 2|doi = 10.1016/0047-2727(73)90002-9|first = Milton|last = Weinstein|first2 = Richard|last2 = Zeckhauser}}</ref>
In the [[United Kingdom]], the [[National Institute for Health and Care Excellence]], which advises on the use of health technologies within the [[National Health Service]], has since at least 2013 used "£ per QALY" to evaluate their utility.<ref name=NICE2013/><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.nice.org.uk/article/pmg9/chapter/6-the-appraisal-of-the-evidence-and-structured-decision-making | title=Guide to the methods of technology appraisal 2013 | publisher=NICE | date=2013 | accessdate=15 Jun 2015 }}</ref>
== History == The concept of the QALY is credited to work by Klarman et al. (1968)<ref>{{Cite journal| volume = 6| issue = 1| pages = 48–54| last = Klarman| first = Herbert E.| first2 = John O'S |last2=Francis |first3=Gerald D. |last3=Rosenthal| title = Cost effectiveness analysis applied to the treatment of chronic renal disease| journal = Medical care| accessdate = 2014-05-06| date = 1968| url = http://journals.lww.com/lww-medicalcare/Abstract/1968/01000/Cost_Effectiveness_Analysis_Applied_to_the.5.aspx| doi=10.1097/00005650-196801000-00005}}</ref>, Fanshel and Bush (1970)<ref>{{Cite journal| volume = 18| issue = 6| pages = 1021–66| last = Fanshel| first = Sol|first2=J.W. |last2=Bush | title = A health-status index and its application to health-services outcomes| journal = Operations Research| accessdate = 2014-05-06| date = 1970| url = http://www.eurohex.eu/bibliography/pdf/0990244687/Fanshel_1970_OR.pdf| doi=10.1287/opre.18.6.1021}}</ref>, and Torrance et al. (1972)<ref>{{Cite journal| issn = 0017-9124| volume = 7| issue = 2| pages = 118–133| last = Torrance| first = G W|first2=W.H. |last2=Thomas |first3=D.L. |last3=Sackett | title = A utility maximization model for evaluation of health care programs| journal = Health services research| date = 1972| pmid = 5044699 | pmc=1067402}}</ref> who suggested the idea of length of life adjusted by indices of functionality or health.<ref>{{Cite book| pages = 31–60| last = Kaplan| first = Robert M.| chapter = Utility assessment for estimating quality-adjusted life years| title = Valuing health care: Costs, benefits, and effectiveness of pharmaceuticals and other medical technologies| accessdate = 2014-05-06| date = 1995| url = http://rmkaplan.bol.ucla.edu/Robert_M._Kaplan/1995_Publications_files/0226.pdf}}</ref> A 1976 article by [[Richard Zeckhauser|Zeckhauser]] and Shepard<ref>{{Cite journal| issn = 0023-9186| volume = 40| issue = 4| pages = 5–45| last = Zeckhauser| first = Richard|first2=Donald |last2=Shepard | title = Where Now for Saving Lives?| journal = Law and Contemporary Problems| date = 1976| url = http://scholarship.law.duke.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3493&context=lcp| doi=10.2307/1191310}}</ref> contained the first known occurrence in print of the term "Quality Adjusted Life Years".<ref name=Sassi2006>{{cite journal|last1=Sassi|first1=Franco|title=Calculating QALYs, comparing QALY and DALY calculations| journal=Health Policy and Planning| volume=21|issue=5|year=2006| pages=402–408|issn=0268-1080|doi=10.1093/heapol/czl018}}</ref> QALYs were later promoted through medical [[technology assessment]]s conducted by the [[US Congress]] [[Office of Technology Assessment]].
Then, in 1980, Pliskin et al. proposed a justification of the construction of the QALY indicator using the multiattribute utility theory: if a set of conditions pertaining to agent preferences on life years and quality of life are verified, then it is possible to express the agent's preferences about couples (number of life years/health state), by an interval (Neumannian) utility function.<ref name=Pliskin1980>{{cite journal |pages=206–24 |doi=10.1287/opre.28.1.206 |jstor=172147 |title=Utility Functions for Life Years and Health Status |year=1980 |last1=Pliskin |first1=J. S. |last2=Shepard |first2=D. S. |last3=Weinstein |first3=M. C. |journal=Operations Research |volume=28}}</ref> This utility function would be equal to the product of an interval utility function on "life years", and an interval utility function on "health state".
== Debate == According to Pliskin et al., the QALY model requires [[utility]] independent, [[risk neutral]], and constant proportional tradeoff behaviour.<ref name=Pliskin1980/> Because of these theoretical assumptions, the meaning and usefulness of the QALY is debated.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite journal |doi=10.1186/1477-7525-1-80 |year=2003 |last1=Prieto |first1=Luis |last2=Sacristán |first2=José A |journal=Health and Quality of Life Outcomes |volume=1 |pages=80 |pmid=14687421 |title=Problems and solutions in calculating quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) |pmc=317370}} {{open access}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1177/0272989X07309642 |title=Comparing the Incomparable? A Systematic Review of Competing Techniques for Converting Descriptive Measures of Health Status into QALY-Weights |year=2007 |last1=Mortimer |first1=D. |last2=Segal |first2=L. |journal=Medical Decision Making |volume=28 |pages=66–89 |pmid=18263562 |issue=1}}</ref> Perfect health is difficult, if not impossible, to define. Some argue that there are health states worse than being dead, and that therefore there should be negative values possible on the health spectrum (indeed, some health economists have incorporated negative values into calculations). Determining the level of health depends on measures that some argue place disproportionate importance on physical pain or disability over mental health.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Dolan |first=P |title=Developing methods that really do value the ‘Q’ in the QALY |journal=Health Economics, Policy and Law |volume=3 |issue=1 |pages=69–77 |year=January 2008 |doi=10.1017/S1744133107004355 |url=http://pauldolan.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/developing-the-methods-that-really-do-value.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref>
The method of ranking interventions on grounds of their cost per QALY gained ratio (or [[Incremental cost-effectiveness ratio|ICER]]) is controversial because it implies a quasi-[[utilitarian]] calculus to determine who will or will not receive treatment.<ref>{{citation| first = Michael | last = Schlander | title = Measures of efficiency in healthcare: QALMs about QALYs? | publisher = Institute for Innovation & Valuation in Health Care | date = 2010-05-23 | location = | url = http://www.michaelschlander.com/pnp/publications_en/Schlander-QALMs-about-QALYs-2010.pdf | doi = | id = | accessdate = 2010-05-23}}</ref> However, its supporters argue that since health care resources are inevitably limited, this method enables them to be allocated in the way that is approximately optimal for society, including most patients. Another concern is that it does not take into account equity issues such as the overall distribution of health states – particularly since younger, healthier cohorts have many times more QALYs than older or sicker individuals. As a result, QALY analysis may undervalue treatments which benefit the elderly or others with a lower life expectancy. Also, many would argue that all else being equal, patients with more severe illness should be prioritised over patients with less severe illness if both would get the same absolute increase in utility.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/(SICI)1099-1050(199902)8:1<25::AID-HEC398>3.0.CO;2-H |title=Incorporating societal concerns for fairness in numerical valuations of health programmes |year=1999 |last1=Nord |first1=Erik |last2=Pinto |first2=Jose Luis |last3=Richardson |first3=Jeff |last4=Menzel |first4=Paul |last5=Ubel |first5=Peter |journal=Health Economics |volume=8 |pages=25–39 |pmid=10082141 |issue=1}}</ref>
As early as 1989, [[Graham Loomes|Loomes]] and McKenzie recommended that research be conducted concerning the validity of QALYs.<ref name=Loomes1989>{{cite journal|last1=Loomes|first1=Graham|last2=McKenzie|first2=Lynda|title=The use of QALYs in health care decision making|journal=Social Science & Medicine|volume=28|issue=4| year=1989|pages=299–308|issn=02779536| doi=10.1016/0277-9536(89)90030-0}}</ref> In 2010, with funding from the [[European Commission]], the European Consortium in Healthcare Outcomes and Cost-Benefit Research (ECHOUTCOME) began a major study on QALYs as used in [[health technology assessment]].<ref name=ECHOUTCOMEhome>{{cite web|url=http://www.echoutcome.eu|title=ECHOUTCOME: European Consortium in Healthcare Outcomes and Cost-Benefit Research|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161008010513/http://echoutcome.eu/|archive-date=2016-10-08 |dead-url=yes }}</ref> [[Ariel Beresniak]], the study's lead author, was quoted as saying that it was the "largest-ever study specifically dedicated to testing the assumptions of the QALY."<ref name=Holmes2013>{{cite journal |last=Holmes |first=David |title=Report triggers quibbles over QALYs, a staple of health metrics |journal=Nature Medicine |volume=19 |issue=3 |pages=248 |date=March 2013 |pmid=23467219 |doi=10.1038/nm0313-248 |url=http://www.nature.com/nm/journal/v19/n3/full/nm0313-248.html}}</ref> In January 2013, at its final conference, ECHOUTCOME released preliminary results of its study which surveyed 1361 people "from academia" in Belgium, France, Italy and the UK.<ref name=Holmes2013/><ref name=BBC>{{cite news |last=Dreaper |first=Jane |title=Researchers claim NHS drug decisions 'are flawed' |newspaper=BBC News |date=24 January 2013 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-21170445|access-date=2017-05-30}}</ref><ref name=Beresniak2015>{{cite journal|last1=Beresniak|first1=Ariel|last2=Medina-Lara|first2=Antonieta|last3=Auray|first3=Jean Paul|last4=De Wever|first4=Alain|last5=Praet|first5=Jean-Claude|last6=Tarricone|first6=Rosanna|last7=Torbica|first7=Aleksandra|last8=Dupont|first8=Danielle|last9=Lamure|first9=Michel|last10=Duru|first10=Gerard|title=Validation of the Underlying Assumptions of the Quality-Adjusted Life-Years Outcome: Results from the ECHOUTCOME European Project|journal=PharmacoEconomics|volume=33|issue=1|year=2015|pages=61–69|issn=1170-7690|doi=10.1007/s40273-014-0216-0}}</ref> The researchers asked the subjects to respond to 14 questions concerning their preferences for various health states and durations of those states (e.g., 15 years limping versus 5 years in a wheelchair).<ref name=Beresniak2015/> They concluded that "preferences expressed by the respondents were not consistent with the QALY theoretical assumptions" that quality of life can be measured in consistent intervals, that life-years and quality of life are independent of each other, that people are neutral about risk, and that willingness to gain or lose life-years is constant over time.<ref name=Beresniak2015/> ECHOUTCOME also released "European Guidelines for Cost-Effectiveness Assessments of Health Technologies," which recommended not using QALYs in healthcare decision making.<ref name=ECHOUTCOMEguidelines>{{cite web|url=http://echoutcome.eu/images/Echoutcome__Leaflet_Guidelines___final.pdf|title=European Guidelines for Cost-Effectiveness Assessments of Health Technologies|author=European Consortium in Healthcare Outcomes and Cost-Benefit Research (ECHOUTCOME)|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150814070546/http://echoutcome.eu/images/Echoutcome__Leaflet_Guidelines___final.pdf|archive-date=2015-08-14 |dead-url=yes }}</ref> Instead, the guidelines recommended that cost-effectiveness analyses focus on "costs per relevant clinical outcome."<ref name=Holmes2013/><ref name=ECHOUTCOMEguidelines/>
In response to the ECHOUTCOME study, representatives of the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence, the [[Scottish Medicines Consortium]], and the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] made the following points. First, QALYs are better than alternative measures.<ref name=Holmes2013/><ref name=BBC/> Second, the study was "limited."<ref name=Holmes2013/><ref name=BBC/> Third, problems with QALYs were already widely acknowledged.<ref name=BBC/> Fourth, the researchers did not take budgetary constraints into consideration.<ref name=BBC/> Fifth, the UK's National Institute for Health and Care Excellence uses QALYs that are based on 3395 interviews with residents of the UK, as opposed to residents of several European countries.<ref name=Holmes2013/> Finally, people who call for the elimination of QALYs may have "[[Conflict of interest|vested interests]]."<ref name=Holmes2013/>
== Future development ==
The UK [[Medical Research Council (United Kingdom)|Medical Research Council]] and others are exploring improvements to or replacements for QALYs.<ref name="Weinstein2009"/><ref name=Brazier2015>{{cite journal|last1=Brazier|first1=John|last2=Tsuchiya|first2=Aki|title=Improving Cross-Sector Comparisons: Going Beyond the Health-Related QALY|journal=Applied Health Economics and Health Policy|volume=13|issue=6|year=2015|pages=557–565|issn=1175-5652|doi=10.1007/s40258-015-0194-1|pmc=4661222|pmid=26324402}}</ref> Among other possibilities are extending the data used to calculate QALYs (e.g., by using different survey instruments); "using well-being to value outcomes" (e.g., by developing a "well-being-adjusted life-year"; and by value outcomes in monetary terms.<ref name=Brazier2015/> Furthermore, researchers are studying whether there should be a [[Social discount rate|discount rate]] for QALYs, and if so whether the rate should be the same as or lower than the rate for costs.<ref name="Weinstein2009"/> In 2018 HM Treasury set a discount rate of 1.5% for QALYs which is lower than the discount rate for other costs and benefits, because the QALY is a direct utility measure.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/the-green-book-appraisal-and-evaluation-in-central-governent|title=HMT Green Book|last=|first=|date=|website=|page=28|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
