revision.text:
[[File:Lichtundurchlässige Pflaster.jpg|thumb|Eye patches may strengthen the weaker eye but fail to stimulate binocular vision and stereopsis, which may sometimes be recovered by different means.]] '''Stereopsis recovery''', also '''recovery from stereoblindness''', is the phenomenon of a [[stereoblind]] person gaining partial or full ability of stereo vision ([[stereopsis]]).
Recovering stereo vision as far as possible has long been established as an approach to the therapeutic treatment of stereoblind patients. Treatment aims to recover stereo vision in very young children, as well as in patients who had acquired but lost their ability for stereopsis due to a medical condition. In contrast, this aim has normally not been present in the treatment of those who missed out on learning stereopsis during their first few years of life. In fact, the acquisition of binocular and stereo vision was long thought to be impossible unless the person acquired this skill during a [[critical period]] in infancy and early childhood.<ref>See for example: {{cite journal|author=Uri Polat|title=Restoration of underdeveloped cortical functions: Evidence from treatment of adult amblyopia|journal=Restorative Neurology and Neuroscience|volume=26|number=4-5|year=2008|pages=413–424}}</ref> This hypothesis normally went unquestioned and has formed the basis for the therapeutic approaches to binocular disorders for decades. It has been put in doubt in recent years. In particular since studies on stereopsis recovery began to appear in scientific journals and it became publicly known that neuroscientist [[Susan R. Barry]] achieved stereopsis well into adulthood, that assumption is in retrospect considered to have held the status of a scientific [[dogma]].<ref name="barry-2009">Susan R. Barry (2009) ''Fixing My Gaze: A Scientist's Journey into Seeing in Three Dimensions''. New York: Basic Books. {{ISBN|978-0-465-02073-7}}</ref><ref>"[…] The book's main contribution, however, is exposing the wrong-headed dogma that acuity and binocular vision can be restored only during a critical developmental period." —''New England Journal of Medicine''. (See introductory pages of: Susan R. Barry (2009) ''Fixing My Gaze.)</ref><ref>"[…] Part memoir and part science, ''Fixing My Gaze'' is a fitting tribute to the determination of a patient and her optometrist in challenging conventional wisdom and dogma." —''Journal of Behavioral Optometry''. (See introductory pages of: Susan R. Barry (2009) ''Fixing My Gaze.)</ref><ref name="astle-etal-2011a">{{cite journal|author1=Andrew T. Astle|author2=Paul V. McGraw|author3=Ben S. Webb|title=Myth exploded: Recovery of stereo acuity in adults with amblyopia|journal=BMJ Case Reports|year=2011|doi=10.1136/bcr.07.2010.3143|pmid=22707543|pmc=3062842|volume=2011|issue=feb21 2|pages=bcr0720103143}}</ref>
Very recently, there has been a rise in scientific investigations into stereopsis recovery in adults and youths who have had no stereo vision before. While it has now been shown that an adult ''may'' gain stereopsis, it is currently not yet possible to predict how likely a stereoblind person is to do so, nor is there general agreement on the best therapeutic procedure. Also the possible implications for the treatment of children with [[infantile esotropia]] are still under study.
== Clinical management of strabismus and stereoblindness == In cases of acquired strabismus with [[double vision]] (diplopia), it is long-established state of the art to aim at curing the double vision and at the same time recovering a patient's earlier ability for stereo vision. For example, a patient may have had full stereo vision but later had diplopia due to a medical condition, losing stereo vision. In this case, medical interventions, including [[vision therapy]] and [[strabismus surgery]], may remove the double vision and recover the stereo vision which had temporarily been absent in the patient.
Also when children with congenital (infantile) strabismus (e.g. [[infantile esotropia]]) receive strabismus surgery within the first few years or two of their life, this goes along with the hope that they may yet develop their full potential for [[binocular vision]] including stereopsis.
In contrast, in a case where a child's eyes are straightened surgically after the age of about five or six years and the child had no opportunity to develop stereo vision in early childhood, normally the clinical expectation is that this intervention will lead to cosmetic improvements but not to stereo vision. Conventionally, no follow-up for stereopsis was performed in such cases.
For instance, one author summarized the accepted scientific view of the time with the words: "Stereopsis will never be obtained unless [[amblyopia]] is treated, the eyes are aligned, and binocular fusion and function are achieved before the critical period for stereopsis ends. Clinical data suggest that this occurs before 24 months of age,[…] but we do not know exactly when it occurs, because crucial pieces of basic science information are missing."<ref>{{cite journal|author=Nigel W. Daw|title=Critical Periods and Amblyopia|journal=Archives of Ophthalmology: Mechanisms of Ophthalmic Disease|date=April 1998|volume=116|number=4|pages=502–505|doi=10.1001/archopht.116.4.502}}</ref> For purposes of illustration, reference is made to a book of doctors' handouts for patients, written for the general public and published in 2002, which summarizes the limitations in the terms in which they, at the time, were fully accepted as [[Medical consensus|medical state of the art]] as follows: "If an adult has a childhood strabismus that was never treated, it is too late to improve any amblyopia or [[depth perception]], so the goal may be simply cosmetic – to make the eyes appear to be properly aligned – though sometimes treatment does enlarge the extent of side vision."<ref>Melvin L. Rubin, Lawrence A. Winograd: ''Taking Care of Your Eyes: A Collection of the Patient Information Handouts Used by America's Leading Eye Doctors'', Triad Records (September 2002), {{ISBN|978-0937404614}}</ref> It has only been accepted very recently that the therapeutic approach was based on an unquestioned notion that has, since, been referred to as "myth" or "dogma".<ref name="astle-etal-2011a"/>
Recently, however, stereopsis recovery is known to have occurred in a number of adults. While this has in some cases occurred after visual exercises or spontaneous visual experiences, recently also the medical community's view of strabismus surgery has become more optimistic with regard to outcomes in terms of binocular function and possibly stereopsis.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=A. Dickmann|author2=S. Aliberti|author3=M.T. Rebecchi|author4=I. Aprile|author5=A. Salerni|author6=S. Petroni|author7=R. Parrilla|author8=V. Perrotta|author9=E. Di Nardo|author10=E. Balestrazzi|title=Improved sensory status and quality-of-life measures in adult patients after strabismus surgery|journal=Journal of AAPOS|date=February 2013|volume=17|number=1|pages=25–28|doi=10.1016/j.jaapos.2012.09.017}}</ref> As one author states: :"The majority of adults will experience some improvement in binocular function after strabismus surgery even if the strabismus has been longstanding. Most commonly this takes the form of an expansion of binocular visual fields; however, some patients may also regain stereopsis."<ref>{{cite journal|title=The efficacy of strabismus surgery in adults: a review for primary care physicians|journal=Postgraduate Medical Journal|date=April 2011|volume=87|number=1026|pages=269–273|doi=10.1136/pgmj.2010.108670}}</ref> Scientific investigations on residual [[neuroplasticity|neural plasticity]] in adulthood now also include studies on the recovery of stereopsis. Now it is a matter of active scientific investigation under which conditions and to which degree binocular fusion and stereo vision can be acquired in adulthood, especially if the person is not known to have had any preceding experience of stereo vision, and how outcomes may depend on the patient's history of therapeutic interventions.
== Examples and case studies == [[File:9.13.09OliverSacksByLuigiNovi.jpg|thumb|[[Oliver Sacks]] was the first to make the story of Susan Barry, whom he nicknamed "Stereo Sue", known to the general public.]] Stereopsis recovery has been reported to have occurred in a few adults as a result of either medical treatments including [[strabismus surgery]] and [[vision therapy]], or spontaneously after a stereoscopic [[3D cinema]] experience.
=== Personal reports in ''Fixing my Gaze'' === The most renowned case of regained stereopsis is that of neuroscientist [[Susan R. Barry]], who had had alternating [[infantile esotropia]] with [[diplopia]], but no amblyopia, underwent three [[Strabismus surgery|surgical corrections]] in childhood without achieving binocular vision at the time, and recovered from stereoblindness in adult age after [[vision therapy]] with optometrist Theresa Ruggiero. Barry's case has been reported on by neurologist [[Oliver Sacks]].<ref name="sacks-2006">{{cite news|author=Oliver Sacks|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2006/06/19/060619fa_fact_sacks |title=Stereo Sue: Why two eyes are better than one|journal=The New Yorker|date=19 June 2006}}</ref> Also [[David H. Hubel]], winner of the 1981 [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine]] with [[Torsten Wiesel]] for their discoveries concerning information processing in the visual system, commented positively on her case.<ref name="barry-2009-p138-140">Susan R. Barry: ''Fixing my Gaze'', 2009, pages 138-140</ref> In 2009, Barry published a book ''Fixing My Gaze: A Scientist's Journey into Seeing in Three Dimensions'', reporting on her own and several other cases of stereopsis recovery.<ref name="barry-2009"/>
In her book ''Fixing my Gaze'', Susan Barry gives a detailed description of her surprise, elation and subsequent experiences when her stereo vision suddenly set in.
Hubel wrote of her book: {{Quote box|“It has been widely thought that an adult, cross-eyed since infancy, could never acquire stereovision, but to everyone's surprise, Barry succeeded. In ''Fixing my Gaze'', she describes how wonderful it was to have, step-by-step, this new 3D world revealed to her. And as a neurobiologist she is able to discuss the science as an expert, in simple language.”|source=David H. Hubel, winner of the Nobel Prize in Physiology/Medicine, John Franklin Enders Professor of Neurobiology, Emeritus, Harvard Medical School.<ref name="barry-2009"/>}}
Her book includes reports of further persons who have had similar experiences with stereopsis recovery. Barry cites the personal experiences of several persons,<!--Comment: the names ofpatients and their optometrists are purposely not listed here in Wikipedia out of respect of their privacy as ordinary people who may not wish to have their names retrieved by search engines, and the names make no difference to the message here--> including a man who was an artist and described his experience of seeing with stereopsis as "that he could see one hundred more times [[negative space]]",<ref>Susan R. Barry: ''Fixing my Gaze'', pages 123</ref> a woman who had been amblyopic before seeing in 3D described how empty space now "looks and feels palpable, tangible—alive!",<ref>Susan R. Barry: ''Fixing my Gaze'', pages 123-124</ref> a woman who had been strabismic since age two and saw in 3D after taking vision therapy and stated that "The coolest thing is the feeling you get being “in the dimension”",<ref>Susan R. Barry: ''Fixing my Gaze'', page 124</ref> a woman who felt quite alarmed at the experience of suddenly seeing roadside trees and signs [[looming]] towards her,<ref>Susan R. Barry: ''Fixing my Gaze'', pages 128-129</ref> and two women who experienced an abrupt onset of stereo vision with a wide-angled view of the world, the first stating: "I was able to take in so much more of the room than I did before" and the second: "It was very dramatic as my [[peripheral vision]] suddenly filled in on both sides".<ref name="barry-p129-131">Susan R. Barry: ''Fixing my Gaze'', pages 129-131</ref>
Common to Barry and at least one person on whom she had reported is the finding that also their [[Visual space|mental representation of space]] changed after having acquired stereo vision: that even with one eye closed the feeling is to see "more" than seeing with one eye closed before recovering stereopsis.<ref name="barry-p129-131"/>
[[File:RealD glasses.jpg|thumb|Although stereoblind, Bridgeman used polarized glasses in a 3D cinema and could suddenly see in 3D.]]
=== Further cases in the media === Apart from Barry, another formerly stereoblind adult whose acquired ability for stereopsis has received media attention is neuroscientist Bruce Bridgeman, professor of psychology and psychobiology at [[University of California Santa Cruz]], who had grown up nearly stereoblind and acquired stereo vision spontaneously in 2012 at the age of 67, when watching the 3D movie [[Hugo (movie)|Hugo]] with polarizing 3D glasses. The scene suddenly appeared to him in depth, and the ability to see the world in stereo stayed with him also after leaving the cinema.<ref>Morgen Peck: [http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120719-awoken-from-a-2d-world/all How a movie changed one man’s vision forever], BBC Future, 19 July 2012</ref><ref>Barry B. Sandrew: [http://bsandrew.blogspot.de/2012/03/how-hugo-gave-one-neuroscientist-gift_630.html Reflections on the Growth of 3D], 19 March 2012 (downloaded 20 July 2013)</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Bruce Bridgeman |url=http://journals.lww.com/optvissci/Abstract/2014/06000/Restoring_Adult_Stereopsis__A_Vision_Researcher_s.17.aspx |title=Restoring Adult Stereopsis: A Vision Researcher’s Personal Experience |journal=Optometry & Vision Science |volume=14 |issue=6 |year=2014 |doi=10.1097/OPX.0000000000000272}}</ref>
== Recent scientific investigations == There is a growing recent body of scientific literature on investigations into the recovery of stereopsis in adults which started to appear shortly before Oliver Sacks' ''The New Yorker'' publication<ref name="sacks-2006"/> drew public attention to Barry's discovery. A number of scientific publications have systematically assessed patients' post-surgical stereopsis,<ref name="kim-etal-2005">{{cite journal|author1=S. Kim|author2=S.T. Yi|author3=Y.A. Cho|url=http://www.koreamed.org/SearchBasic.php?RID=0035JKOS/2005.46.11.1831&DT=1|title=Postoperative Recovery of Stereopsis in Longstanding Adult Constant-Horizontal Strabismus|journal=Journal of the Korean Ophthalmological Society|date=November 2005|volume=46|number=11|pages=1831–1836|language=Korean}}</ref><ref name="gharabaghi-azadeh-2006">{{cite journal|author1=Davood Gharabaghi|author2=Minoo Azadeh|title=Binocular vision and stereopsis following delayed strabismus surgery|journal=Iranian Journal of Ophthalmology|year=2006|volume=19|number=2|pages=46–50}} ([http://www.sid.ir/en/ViewPaper.asp?ID=85592&vDate=2006&vEnd=50&vJournal=IRANIAN+JOURNAL+OF+OPHTHALMOLOGY&vNo=2&vStart=46&vVolume=19&vWriter=GHARAHBAGHI%20D.,AZADEH%20M. abstract], [http://www.irjo.org/browse.php?a_id=573&slc_lang=en&sid=1&ftxt=1&ei=yKLqUaDPGonpPJbngMgB&usg=AFQjCNEvTf5HwGPOClNMCjmmW3HjfaLOew&bvm=bv.49478099,d.ZWU full text])</ref><ref name="fatima-etal-2009">{{cite journal|author1=Tarannum Fatima|author2=Abadan K Amitava|author3=Saba Siddiqui|author4=Mohammad Ashraf|title=Gains beyond cosmesis: Recovery of fusion and stereopsis in adults with longstanding strabismus following successful surgical realignment|journal=Indian Journal of Ophthalmology|date=March–April 2009|volume=57|number=2|pages=141–143|doi=10.4103/0301-4738.45505}}</ref> whereas other studies have investigated the effects of eye training procedures.<ref name="ding-levi-2011a">{{cite journal|author1=Jian Ding|author2=Dennis M. Levi|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/108/37/E733.full|title=Recovery of stereopsis through perceptual learning in human adults with abnormal binocular vision|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|date=September 2011|volume=108|number=37|pages=15035–15036|doi=10.1073/pnas.1105183108|pmc=3174650}}</ref><ref name="ding-levi-2011b">{{cite news|author1=Jian Ding|author2=Dennis M. Levi|url=http://f1000.com/posters/browse/summary/1089361|title=The spatial limits of recovered stereopsis in strabismic/amblyopic adults|conference=European Conference on Visual Perception 2011, 28 August - 1 September 2011, 64}} ([http://cdn.f1000.com/posters/docs/66836449 full text])</ref><ref name="vedamurthy-etal-2012">{{cite journal|author1=Indu Vedamurthy|author2=Samuel J. Huang|author3=Dennis M. Levi|author4=Daphne Bavelier|author5=David C. Knill|title=Recovery of stereopsis in adults through training in a virtual reality task|journal=Journal of Vision|date=27 December 2012|volume=12|number=14|doi=10.1167/12.14.53|pages=53}} Article 53</ref>
=== Post-surgical stereopsis === Certain conditions are known to be a prerequisite for stereo vision, for instance, that the amount of horizontal deviation, if any is present, needs to be small.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=David A. Leske|author2=Jonathan M. Holmes|title=Maximum angle of horizontal strabismus consistent with true stereopsis|journal=Journal of American Association for Pediatric Ophthalmology and Strabismus|volume=8|number=1|date=February 2004|pages=28–34|doi=10.1016/j.jaapos.2003.08.010}}</ref> In several studies it has been recognized that surgery to correct strabismus can have the effect of improving binocular function.<ref>{{cite journal|author=John D. Baker|title=The value of adult strabismus correction to the patient|journal=Journal of American Association for Pediatric Ophthalmology and Strabismus|volume=6|number=3|date=June 2002|pages=136–140|doi=10.1067/mpa.2002.123430}}</ref><ref name="mets-etal-2003">{{cite journal|author1=Marilyn B. Mets|author2=Cynthia Beauchamp|author3=Betty Anne Haldi|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1358989/pdf/14971578.pdf|title=Binocularity following surgical correction of strabismus in adults|journal=Transactions of the American Ophthalmological Society|year=2003|number=101|pages=201–207|pmc=1358989|pmid=14971578|volume=101}}</ref> One of these studies, published in 2003, explicitly concluded: "We found that improvement in binocularity, including stereopsis, can be obtained in a substantial portion of adults."<ref name="mets-etal-2003"/> That article was published together with a discussion of the results among peers in which the scientific and social implications of the medical treatment were addressed, for example concerning the long-term relevancy of stereopsis, the importance of avoiding diplopia, the necessity of predictable outcomes, and [[Stereopsis#Prelevance and impact|psychosocial and socioeconomic relevance]].<ref name="mets-etal-2003"/>
Among the investigations into post-surgical stereopsis is a publication of 2005 that reported on a total of 43 adults over 18 years of age who had surgical correction after having lived with from constant-horizontal strabismus for more than 10 years with no previous surgery or stereopsis, with visual acuity of 20/40 or more also in the deviating eye; in this group, stereopsis was present in 80% of exotropes and 31% of esotropes, with the recovery of stereopsis and stereoacuity being uncorrelated to the number of years the deviation had persisted.<ref name="kim-etal-2005"/> A study that was published 2006 included, aside an extensive review of investigations on stereopsis recovery of the last decades, a re-evaluation of all those patients who had had congenital or early-onset strabismus with a large constant horizontal divergence and had undergone strabismus surgery in the years 1997–1999 in a given clinic, excluding those who had a history of neurologic or systemic diseases or with organic retinal diseases. Among the resulting 36 subjects aged 6–30 years, many had regained binocular vision (56% according to an evaluation with [[Bagolini Striated Glasses Test|Bagolini striated glasses]], 39% with Titmus test, 33% with [[Worth 4 dot test|Worth 4-dot]] test, and 22% with Random dot E test) and 57% had stereoacuity of 200 [[Second of arc|sec of arc]] of better, leading to the conclusion that some degrees of stereopsis can be achieved even in cases of infantile or early-childhood strabism.<ref name="gharabaghi-azadeh-2006"/> Another study found that some chronically strabismic adults with good vision could recover fusion and stereopsis by means of surgical alignment.<ref name="fatima-etal-2009"/>
In contrast, in a study in which a group of 17 adults and older children of at least 8 years of age, all of whom received strabismus surgery and post-operative evaluation after long-standing untreated [[infantile esotropia]], most showed binocular fusion when tested with Bagolini lenses and an increased [[visual field]], but none demonstrated stereo fusion or stereopsis.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Anthony David Neil Murray|author2=Jane Orpen|author3=Carolyn Calcutt|title=Changes in the functional binocular status of older children and adults with previously untreated infantile esotropia following late surgical realignment|journal=Journal of American Association for Pediatric Ophthalmology and Strabismus|volume=11|number=2|date=April 2007|pages=125–130|doi=10.1016/j.jaapos.2006.10.016}}</ref>
[[Stereoacuity]] is limited by the [[visual acuity]] of the eyes, and in particular by the visual acuity of the weaker eye. That is, the more a patient's vision of any one of the two eyes is degraded compared to the 20/20 vision standard, the lower are the prospects of improving or re-gaining stereo vision, unless visual acuity itself were improved by other means. Strabismus surgery itself does not improve visual acuity.
=== Stereopsis following training procedures === [[Eye exercises|Orthoptic exercises]] have proven to be effective for reducing symptoms in patients with convergence insufficiency and decompensating [[exophoria]] by improving the near-point convergence of the eyes that is necessary for binocular fusion.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=S. Aziz|author2=M. Cleary|author3=H.K. Stewart|author4=C.R. Weir|title=Are orthoptic exercises an effective treatment for convergence and fusion deficiencies?|journal=Strabismus|date=December 2006|volume=14|number=|pages=183–189|pmid=17162439|doi=10.1080/09273970601026185|issue=4}}</ref>
Experiments on monkeys, published 2007, revealed improvements in stereoacuity in monkeys who, after having been raised with binocular deptivation through prisms for the first two years, were exposed to extensive psychophysical training. Their stereo vision recovered in part, but remained far more limited than that of normally raised monkeys.<ref>{{cite journal|author=C. Nakatsuka|title=Effects of Perceptual Learning on Local Stereopsis and Neuronal Responses of V1 and V2 in Prism-Reared Monkeys|journal=AJP: Journal of Neurophysiology|date=April 2007|volume=97|number=4|pages=2612–2626|doi=10.1152/jn.01001.2006|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
Scientists at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] have stated that [[perceptual learning]] appears to play an important role.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Dennis M. Levi|title=Perceptual learning in adults with amblyopia: A reevaluation of critical periods in human vision|journal=Developmental Psychobiology|volume=46|number=3|pages=222–232|date=April 2005|doi=10.1002/dev.20050}}</ref> One investigation, published 2011, reported on a study on human stereopsis recovery using [[perceptual learning]] which was inspired by Barry's work. In this study, a small number of stereoblind subjects who had initially been stereoblind or stereoanomalous recovered stereopsis using perceptual learning exercises. Alongside the scientific assessment of the extent of recovery, also the subjective outcomes are described: "After achieving stereopsis, our observers reported that the depth “popped out,” which they found very helpful and joyful in their everyday life. The anisometropic observer GD noticed “a surge in depth” one day when shopping in a supermarket. While playing table tennis, she feels that she is able to track a ping-pong ball more accurately and therefore can play better. Strabismic observer AB is more confident now when walking down stairs because she can judge the depth of the steps better. Strabismics AB, DP, and LR, are able to enjoy 3D movies for the first time, and strabismic GJ finds it easier to catch a fly ball while playing baseball."<ref name="ding-levi-2011a"/> In a follow-up study, the authors of this study pointed out that the stereopsis that was recovered following perceptual learning was more limited in resolution and precision compared to normal subjects' stereopsis.<ref name="ding-levi-2011b"/> [[Dennis M. Levi]] was awarded the 2011 Charles F. Prentice Medal of the [[American Academy of Optometry]] for this work.<ref>[http://www.aaopt.org/About/Prentice Charles F. Prentice Medal], American Academy of Optometry (downloaded 22 July 2013)</ref><ref>[http://optometry.berkeley.edu/pdf-s/berkoptmagazine_2012sml.pdf Berkeley Optometry magazine], Vol. 5, No. 1, Fall 2012 (downloaded 22 July 2013)</ref><ref name="pmid22581119"/>
[[File:Emacs Tetris vector based detail.svg|upright|thumb|[[Tetris]] is a popular video game from the 1980s. A modified version of the game (not shown here) has been used for dichoptic training.]] There have been several attempts to make use of modern technology for enhanced binocular eye training, in particular for treating [[amblyopia]] and [[Suppression (eye)|interocular suppression]]. In some cases these modern techniques have improved patients' stereoacuity. Very early technology-enhanced vision therapy efforts have included the [[cheiroscope]], which is a [[haploscope]] in which left- and or right-eye images can be blended into view over a drawing pad, and the subject may be given a task such as to reproduce a line image presented to one eye. However, historically these approaches were not developed much further and they were not put to widespread use. Recent systems are based on [[dichoptic presentation]] of the elements of a [[video game]] or [[virtual reality]] such that each eye receives different signals of the virtual world that the player's brain must combine in order to play successfully.
One of the earliest systems of this kind has been proposed by a research group in the [[University of Nottingham]] with the aim of treating amblyopia, using virtual reality masks<ref>[http://www.google.com/patents/WO2003092482A1?hl=en Patent WO2003092482 A1 Ocular display apparatus for assessment and measurement of and for treatment of ocular disorders, and methods therefor], priority date 4 May 2002, publication date 13 November 2003, Isabel Ash et al.</ref><ref name="eastgate-etal-2006">{{cite journal |vauthors=Eastgate RM, Griffiths GD, Waddingham PE, Moody AD, Butler TK, Cobb SV, Comaish IF, Haworth SM, Gregson RM, Ash IM, Brown SM |title=Modified virtual reality technology for treatment of amblyopia |journal=Eye (London, England) |volume=20 |issue=3 |pages=370–4 | date=March 2006 |pmid=15832182 |doi=10.1038/sj.eye.6701882 |url= |issn=}}</ref><ref name="bbc">{{cite news|author=Gareth Mitchell|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/4849244.stm|journal=BBC News|title=Video games tackle 'lazy eye'|date=28 March 2006}}</ref> or commercially available [[Active shutter 3D system|3D shutter glasses]].<ref>{{cite journal|author1=N. Herbison|author2=S. Cobb|author3=R. Gregson|author4=I. Ash|author5=R. Eastgate|author6=J. Purdy|author7=T. Hepburn|author8=D. Mackeith|author9=A. Foss|title=Interactive binocular treatment (I-BiT) for amblyopia: results of a pilot study of 3D shutter glasses system|journal=Eye|date=28 June 2013|doi=10.1038/eye.2013.113|volume=27|issue=9|pages=1077–1083|pmc=3772355}}</ref> The group also has worked to develop perceptual learning training protocols that specifically target the deficit in [[Stereoscopic acuity|stereo acuity]] to allow the recovery of normal stereo function even in adulthood.<ref name="astle-etal-2011b">{{cite journal|author1=Andrew T. Astle|author2=Paul V. McGraw|author3=Ben S. Webb|title=Can Human Amblyopia be Treated in Adulthood?|journal=Strabismus|date=September 2011|volume=19|number=3|pages=99–109|doi=10.3109/09273972.2011.600420|pmc=3433677}}</ref>
Another system of dichoptic presentation for binocular vision therapy has been proposed by researchers of the Research Institute of the [[McGill University]] Health Centre.<ref>[http://www.google.com/patents/WO2009053917A1?hl=en Patent WO 2009053917 A1 Binocular vision assessment and/or therapy], priority date 23 October 2007, publication date 30 April 2009, Robert F. Hess et al.</ref> Using a modified [[puzzle video game]] ''[[Tetris]]'',<ref>{{cite news|author=Joseph Nordqvist|url=http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/259547.php|title=Tetris Video Game Helps Treat Lazy Eye|journal=Medical News Today (MNT)|date=23 April 2013}}</ref> the [[Suppression (eye)|interocular suppression]] of patients with amblyopia was successfully treated with dichotomic training in which certain parameters of the training material were systematically adapted during the course of four weeks. Clinical supervision of such procedures is required to ensure that double vision does not occur. Most of the patients who underwent this treatment gained improved visual acuity of the weaker eye, and some also showed increased stereoacuity.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Black JM, Hess RF, Cooperstock JR, To L, Thompson B |title=The measurement and treatment of suppression in amblyopia |journal=Journal of Visualized Experiments|volume= |issue=70 |pages=e3927 |year=2012 |pmid=23271400 |pmc=3575204 |doi=10.3791/3927 |url= |issn=}} (with video clip explaining the procedure)</ref> Another study performed at the same institute showed that dichoptic training can be more effective in adults than the more conventional amblyopia treatment of an [[eye patch]]. For this investigation, 18 adults played the game Tetris for one hour each day, half of the group wearing eye patches and the other half playing a dichoptic version of the game. After two weeks, the group who played dichoptically showed a significant improvement of vision in the weaker eye and in stereopsis acuity; the eye patch group had moderate improvements, which increased substantially after they, too, were given the dichoptic training afterwards.<ref name="li-etal-2013">{{cite journal|author1=Jinrong Li|author2=Benjamin Thompson|author3=Daming Deng|author4=Lily Y.L. Chan|author5=Minbin Yu|author6=Robert F. Hess|url=http://www.nature.com/eye/journal/v20/n3/full/6701882a.html|title=Dichoptic training enables the adult amblyopic brain to learn|journal=Current Biology|year=2013|volume=23|number=8|pages=R308–309|doi=10.1016/j.cub.2013.01.059|pmid=23618662}}</ref><ref name="li-review">Review of the Li et al (2013) article in: {{cite journal|title=Tetris as treatment|journal=Student BMJ|year=2013|number=21|page=f3332|doi=10.1136/sbmj.f3332}}</ref> Dichoptic-based perceptual learning therapy, presented by means of a head-mounted display, is amenable also to amblyopic children, as it improves both the amblyopic eye's visual acuity and the stereo function.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Pamela J. Knox|author2=Anita J. Simmers|author3=Lyle S. Gray|author4=Marie Cleary|url=http://www.iovs.org/content/53/2/817.full.pdf|title=An exploratory study: Prolonged periods of binocular stimulation can provide an effective treatment for childhood amblyopia|journal=Investigative Ophthalmology & Visual Science|date=February 2012|volume=53|number=2|doi=10.1167/iovs.11-8219|pages=817–824|pmid=22169103}}</ref> The researchers at McGill University have shown that one to three weeks of playing a dichoptic video game for one to two hours on a hand-held device "can improve acuity and restore binocular function, including stereopsis in adults".<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 23231369 | year = 2012 | author1 = Hess | first1 = R. F. | title = An i ''Pod'' treatment of amblyopia: An updated binocular approach | journal = Optometry (St. Louis, Mo.) | volume = 83 | issue = 2 | pages = 87–94 | last2 = Thompson | first2 = B | last3 = Black | first3 = J. M. | last4 = Machara | first4 = G | last5 = Zhang | first5 = P | last6 = Bobier | first6 = W. R. | last7 = Cooperstock | first7 = J }}</ref> Furthermore, it has been suggested that these effect can be enhanced by anodal transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS).<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Hess Robert F. |author2=Thompson Benjamin |author3=Baker Daniel H. | year = 2014 | title = Binocular vision in amblyopia: structure, suppression and plasticity | url = | journal = Ophthalmic and Physiological Optics | volume = 34 | issue = 2| pages = 146–162 | doi=10.1111/opo.12123}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Spiegel D. P. | year = 2013 | title = Transcranial direct current stimulation enhances recovery of stereopsis in adults with amblyopia | url = https://www.researchgate.net/publication/249647953_Transcranial_Direct_Current_Stimulation_Enhances_Recovery_of_Stereopsis_in_Adults_With_Amblyopia | journal = Neurotherapeutics | volume = 10 | issue = 4| pages = 831–839 | doi=10.1007/s13311-013-0200-y|display-authors=etal| pmc = 3805870}}</ref>
Together with Levi of the University of California, Berkeley, scientists at the [[University of Rochester]] have made further developments in terms of virtual reality computer games<ref name="vedamurthy-etal-2012"/><ref>[http://www.google.ca/patents/US20120179076?hl=en Patent US20120179076 A1 Method and system for treating amblyopia], priority date 16 September 2010, filing date 16 September 2011, publication date 12 July 2012, Daphne Bavelier et al.</ref> which have shown some promise in improving both monocular and [[binocular vision]] in human subjects.
Game developer James Blaha, who developed his own [[crowd-funding|crowd-funded]] version of a dichoptic VR game for the [[Oculus Rift]] together with Manish Gupta and is continuing to experiment with the game, experienced steropsis for the first time using his game.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Blaha James |author2=Gupta Manish | year = | title = Diplopia: A virtual reality game designed to help amblyopics | url = | journal = Virtual Reality | volume = 2014 | issue = | pages = 163–164 | doi = 10.1109/VR.2014.6802102 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.podtrac.com/pts/redirect.mp3/www.reverendkyle.com/media/com_podcastmanager/revvr_podcast_47.mp3 Reverend VR Podcast with James Rift]</ref> In 2011, two cases of adults with [[Anisometropia|anisometropic]] amblyopia were reported whose visual acuity and stereoacuity improved due to learning-based therapies.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Astle AT, McGraw PV, Webb BS |title=Recovery of stereo acuity in adults with amblyopia |journal=[[BMJ]] Case Reports |volume=2011 |issue= feb21 2|pages= bcr0720103143|year=2011 |pmid=22707543 |pmc=3062842 |doi=10.1136/bcr.07.2010.3143 |url=}} Cited in: {{cite journal |author=Levi DM |title=Prentice award lecture 2011: Removing the brakes on plasticity in the amblyopic brain |journal=Optometry and Vision Science |volume=89 |issue=6 |pages=827–38 | date=June 2012 |pmid=22581119 |pmc=3369432 |doi=10.1097/OPX.0b013e318257a187 |url= |issn=}}</ref>
There are indications that the suppression of binocularity in amblyopic subjects is due to a suppression mechanism that prevents the amblyopic brain from learning to see.<ref name="li-etal-2013"/><ref name="li-review"/> It has been suggested that desuppression and neuroplasticity may be favored by specific conditions that are commonly associated with perceptual learning tasks and video game playing such as a heightened requirement of [[attention]], a [[incentive|prospect of reward]], a feeling of [[enjoyment]] and a sense of [[Flow (psychology)|flow]].<ref name="pmid22581119">{{cite journal |author=Levi DM |title=Prentice award lecture 2011: Removing the brakes on plasticity in the amblyopic brain |journal=Optometry and Vision Science |volume=89 |issue=6 |pages=827–38 | date=June 2012 |pmid=22581119 |pmc=3369432 |doi=10.1097/OPX.0b013e318257a187 |url= |issn=}}</ref><ref name="baroncelli-etal-2011">{{cite journal|author1=Laura Baroncelli|author2=Lamberto Maffei|author3=Alessandro Sale|title=New Perspectives in Amblyopia Therapy on Adults: A Critical Role for the Excitatory/Inhibitory Balance|journal=Front Cell Neurosci|year=2011|volume=5|number=25|doi=10.3389/fncel.2011.00025|pmc=3223381|pmid=22144947}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author1=D. Bavelier|author2=D.M. Levi|author3=R.W. Li|author4=Y. Dan|author5=T.K. Hensch|title=Removing brakes on adult brain plasticity: from molecular to behavioral interventions|journal=The Journal of Neuroscience|date=November 2010|volume=30|number=45|pages=14964–14971|doi=10.1523/JNEUROSCI.4812-10.2010|pmc=2992973|pmid=21068299}}</ref>
== Health care policy matters == [[File:Prismenglaeser2.jpg|thumb|Prism lenses (here unusually thick) are used for pre-operative prism adaptation.]] Health insurances always review therapies in terms of [[Clinical governance#Clinical effectiveness|clinical effectiveness]] in view of existing scientific literature, benefit, risk and cost. Even if individual cases of recovery exist, a treatment is only considered effective under this point of view if there is sufficient likelihood that it will predictably improve outcomes.
In this context, medical coverage policy of the global health services organization [[Cigna]] "does not cover [[vision therapy]], [[Optometry|optometric]] [[Vision training|training]], [[eye exercises]] or [[orthoptics]] because they are considered experimental, investigational or unproven for any indication including the management of visual disorders and learning disabilities" based on a bibliographic review published by Cigna which concludes that "insufficient evidence exists in the published, [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]] literature to conclude that vision therapy is effective for the treatment of any of the strabismic disorders except preoperative [[prism]] adaptation for acquired esotropia".<ref>[https://cignaforhcp.cigna.com/public/content/pdf/coveragePolicies/medical/mm_0221_coveragepositioncriteria_vision_therapy_orthoptics.pdf Cigna Medical Coverage Policy], Coverage policy number 0221, effective 15 November 2012, for review 15 November 2013 (downloaded 20 July 2013)</ref> Similarly, the U.S. [[managed health care]] company [[Aetna]] offers vision therapy only in contracts with [[Health insurance in the United States#Supplemental coverage|supplemental coverage]] and limits its prescriptions to a number of conditions that are explicitly specified in a list of vision disorders.<ref>[http://www.aetna.com/cpb/medical/data/400_499/0489.html Clinical policy bulletins: Vision therapy], Number 0489, 4 June 2013, for review 13 June 2013 (downloaded 21 July 2013)</ref>

Increment when new seasons/series begin. See template documentation for more info.--> | num_episodes = 4 <!-- Value is incremented when new episodes air. See template documentation for more info.--> | list_episodes = | executive_producer = | producer = Mark McNeill | editor = Irena Dol | location = | cinematography = | camera = | runtime = <!-- Reliable source required --> | company = Razor Films | distributor = | budget = | network = [[Television New Zealand]] | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = <!-- The nation in which the series first aired, if different from country parameter --> | released = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | first_aired = {{Start date|2016|5|31|df=y}} | last_aired = {{End date|2016|6|21|df=y}} | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = <!-- To be used only for remakes, spin-offs, and adaptations --> | website = <!-- Remove or comment out this parameter line completely if URL exists on or is moved to Wikidata --> | website_title = | production_website = http://razorfilms.co.nz/work/predict-my-future/ | production_website_title = }} '''''Why Am I?: The Science of Us''''' (also known as '''''Predict My Future: The Science of Us''''') is a 2016 New Zealand documentary series about the [[Dunedin Multidisciplinary Health and Development Study]], a [[longitudinal study|long-running]] [[cohort study]] following 1037 people born in [[Dunedin]], New Zealand during 1972 and 1973. The study revealed the result of the combined effects of hereditary (genes) and environment (upbringing) on how people turn out.
The series of four sixty minute episodes was made by Razor Films of [[Auckland]], New Zealand, and screened on [[TV One (New Zealand)|TV One]] from 31 May to 21 June 2016, with all four episodes available online on TVNZ On Demand.
The series follows the study and information it has provided in almost every field of medical and social development including respiratory and cardiovascular health, addictions, obesity, sexual health, cognitive neuroscience, psychiatry, genetics and criminology and the effects of nature and nurture on health and behaviour.
